Get the mean number of records before filtration.

Args: data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data with 'animal_id' and 'time' columns.

Returns: int: mean number of records.

@staticmethod
def get_std_records_no_before_filtration(data: humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame) -> int: 
643    @staticmethod
644    def get_std_records_no_before_filtration(data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> int:
645        """
646        Get the mean number of records
647        before filtration.
648
649        Args:
650            data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data with 'animal_id'
651                and 'time' columns.
652
653        Returns:
654            int: mean number of records.
655        """
656
657        records_counts = data.reset_index().groupby("user_id").datetime.count()
658
659        try:
660            return int(records_counts.std())  # type: ignore
661        except:
662            return 0  # type: ignore

Get the mean number of records before filtration.

Args: data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data with 'animal_id' and 'time' columns.

Returns: int: mean number of records.

@staticmethod
def get_mean_periods( data: humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame) -> pandas._libs.tslibs.timedeltas.Timedelta: 
665    @staticmethod
666    def get_mean_periods(data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> pd.Timedelta:
667        """
668        Get the mean period between start and end times.
669
670        Args:
671            data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data with 'start'
672                and 'end' columns.
673
674        Returns:
675            float: The mean period in days.
676        """
677
678        return (
679            data.groupby("user_id")["end"].max() - data.groupby("user_id")["start"].min()
680        ).mean()  # type: ignore

Get the mean period between start and end times.

Args: data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data with 'start' and 'end' columns.

Returns: float: The mean period in days.

@staticmethod
def get_min_periods( data: humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame) -> pandas._libs.tslibs.timedeltas.Timedelta: 
683    @staticmethod
684    def get_min_periods(data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> pd.Timedelta:
685        """
686        Get the minimum period between start and end times.
687
688        Args:
689            data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data with 'start'
690                and 'end' columns.
691
692        Returns:
693            float: The minimum period in days.
694        """
695
696        return (
697            data.groupby("user_id")["end"].max() - data.groupby("user_id")["start"].min()
698        ).min()  # type: ignore

Get the minimum period between start and end times.

Args: data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data with 'start' and 'end' columns.

Returns: float: The minimum period in days.

@staticmethod
def get_max_periods( data: humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame) -> pandas._libs.tslibs.timedeltas.Timedelta: 
701    @staticmethod
702    def get_max_periods(data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> pd.Timedelta:
703        """
704        Get the maximum period between start and end times.
705
706        Args:
707            data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data with 'start'
708                and 'end' columns.
709
710        Returns:
711            float: The maximum period in days.
712        """
713
714        return (
715            data.groupby("user_id")["end"].max() - data.groupby("user_id")["start"].min()
716        ).max()  # type: ignore

Args: data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data with 'start' and 'end' columns.

Returns: float: The maximum period in days.

@staticmethod
def get_std_periods( data: humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame) -> pandas._libs.tslibs.timedeltas.Timedelta: 
719    @staticmethod
720    def get_std_periods(data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> pd.Timedelta:
721        """
722        Get the std of period between start and end times.
723
724        Args:
725            data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data with 'start'
726                and 'end' columns.
727
728        Returns:
729            float: The std period in days.
730        """
731
732        try:
733            return (
734                data.groupby("user_id")["end"].max() - data.groupby("user_id")["start"].min()
735            ).std()  # type: ignore
736        except:
737            return 0  # type: ignore

Get the std of period between start and end times.

Args: data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data with 'start' and 'end' columns.

Returns: float: The std period in days.

@staticmethod
def get_overall_area(data: humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame) -> float: 
740    @staticmethod
741    def get_overall_area(data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> float:
742        """
743        Get the overall area covered by the trajectories.
744
745        Args:
746            data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input spatial data.
747
748        Returns:
749            float: The overall area in hectares.
750
751        """
752
753        convex_hull = data.unary_union.convex_hull
754
755        return round(convex_hull.area / 10000, 0)

Get the overall area covered by the trajectories.

Args: data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input spatial data.

Returns: float: The overall area in hectares.

@staticmethod
def get_mean_area(data: humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame) -> float: 
758    @staticmethod
759    def get_mean_area(data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> float:
760        """
761        Get the mean area covered by trajectories per user.
762
763        Args:
764            data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data.
765
766        Returns:
767            float: The mean area in hectares.
768        """
769
770        grouped = data.copy().groupby("user_id")
771        areas = []
772        for user_id, group in grouped:
773            convex_hull = group.unary_union.convex_hull
774            areas.append(convex_hull.area / 10000)
775
776        return round(sum(areas) / len(areas), 0)

Get the mean area covered by trajectories per user.

Args: data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data.

Returns: float: The mean area in hectares.

@staticmethod
def get_min_area(data: humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame) -> float: 
779    @staticmethod
780    def get_min_area(data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> float:
781        """
782        Get the min area covered by trajectories per user.
783
784        Args:
785            data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data.
786
787        Returns:
788            float: The min area in hectares.
789        """
790
791        grouped = data.copy().groupby("user_id")
792        areas = []
793        for user_id, group in grouped:
794            convex_hull = group.unary_union.convex_hull
795            areas.append(convex_hull.area / 10000)
796
797        return round(min(areas), 0)

Get the min area covered by trajectories per user.

Args: data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data.

Returns: float: The min area in hectares.

@staticmethod
def get_max_area(data: humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame) -> float: 
800    @staticmethod
801    def get_max_area(data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> float:
802        """
803        Get the max area covered by trajectories per user.
804
805        Args:
806            data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data.
807
808        Returns:
809            float: The max area in hectares.
810        """
811
812        grouped = data.copy().groupby("user_id")
813        areas = []
814        for user_id, group in grouped:
815            convex_hull = group.unary_union.convex_hull
816            areas.append(convex_hull.area / 10000)
817
818        return round(max(areas), 0)

Get the max area covered by trajectories per user.

Args: data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data.

Returns: float: The max area in hectares.

@staticmethod
def get_std_area(data: humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame) -> float: 
821    @staticmethod
822    def get_std_area(data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> float:
823        """
824        Get the std of area covered by trajectories per user.
825
826        Args:
827            data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data.
828
829        Returns:
830            float: The std of area in hectares.
831        """
832
833        grouped = data.copy().groupby("user_id")
834        areas = []
835        for user_id, group in grouped:
836            convex_hull = group.unary_union.convex_hull
837            areas.append(convex_hull.area / 10000)
838
839        try:
840            return round(std(areas), 0)
841        except:
842            return 0

Get the std of area covered by trajectories per user.

Args: data (TrajectoriesFrame): Input data.

Returns: float: The std of area in hectares.

class DataSetStats: 
846class DataSetStats:
847    """
848    A class for managing dataset statistics, storing various statistical
849    measures, and saving them into a structured DataFrame.
850
851    Attributes:
852        output_dir (str): Directory to save the dataset statistics.
853        record (dict): A dictionary to store temporary statistics
854            before adding them to the dataset.
855        stats_set (pd.DataFrame): A DataFrame containing all the
856            statistics collected for different datasets.
857    """
858
859    def __init__(self, output_dir) -> None:
860        """
861        Initializes the DataSetStats class.
862
863        Args:
864            output_dir (str): The directory where output files
865                will be stored.
866        """
867
868        self.output_dir = output_dir
869        self.record = {}
870        self.stats_set = pd.DataFrame(
871            columns=[
872                "animal",
873                "animal_no",
874                "animal_after_filtration",
875                "time_period",
876                "min_label_no",
877                "mean_label_no",
878                "std_label_no",
879                "min_records",
880                "mean_records",
881                "std_records",
882                "avg_duration",
883                "std_duration",
884                "min_duration",
885                "max_duration",
886                "overall_set_area",
887                "average_set_area",
888                "min_area",
889                "max_area",
890                "std_area",
891                "visitation_frequency",
892                "visitation_frequency_params",
893                "distinct_locations_over_time",
894                "distinct_locations_over_time_params",
895                "jump_lengths_distribution",
896                "jump_lengths_distribution_params",
897                "waiting_times",
898                "waiting_times_params",
899                "msd_curve",
900                "msd_curve_params",
901                # "travel_times",
902                # "travel_times_params",
903                # "rog",
904                # "rog_params",
905                "rog_over_time",
906                "rog_over_time_params",
907                "msd_distribution",
908                "msd_distribution_params",
909                # "return_time_distribution",
910                # "return_time_distribution_params",
911                # "exploration_time",
912                # "exploration_time_params",
913                "rho",
914                "gamma",
915            ]
916        )
917
918
919    def add_data(self, data: dict) -> None:
920        """
921        Updates the record dictionary with new data.
922
923        Args:
924            data (dict): A dictionary containing key-value
925                pairs of statistics to be added.
926        """
927
928        self.record.update((data))
929
930
931    def add_record(self) -> None:
932        """
933        Adds the current record to the stats_set DataFrame
934        and resets the record dictionary.
935        """
936
937        self.stats_set = pd.concat(
938            [
939                self.stats_set,
940                pd.DataFrame([self.record])
941            ],
942            ignore_index=True)  # type: ignore
943        self.record = {}

A class for managing dataset statistics, storing various statistical measures, and saving them into a structured DataFrame.

Attributes: output_dir (str): Directory to save the dataset statistics. record (dict): A dictionary to store temporary statistics before adding them to the dataset. stats_set (pd.DataFrame): A DataFrame containing all the statistics collected for different datasets.

class Prepocessing: 
 947class Prepocessing:
 948    """
 949    A class containing static methods for preprocessing animal
 950    trajectory data.
 951    """
 952
 953    def __init__(self) -> None:
 954        """
 955        Initializes the Prepocessing class.
 956        """
 957        pass
 958
 959
 960    @staticmethod
 961    def get_mean_points(data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> TrajectoriesFrame:
 962        """
 963        Computes the mean latitude and longitude for each label.
 964
 965        Args:
 966            data (TrajectoriesFrame): The trajectory dataset.
 967
 968        Returns:
 969            TrajectoriesFrame: A new dataset with averaged locations
 970                per label.
 971        """
 972
 973        basic_df = data.reset_index()
 974        geometry_df = pd.DataFrame()
 975        for an_id, values in tqdm(
 976            data.groupby(level=0), total=len(data.groupby(level=0))
 977        ):
 978            filtered_df = basic_df[basic_df["user_id"] == an_id]
 979            lables_pack = sorted(filtered_df["labels"].unique())
 980
 981            for lbl in lables_pack:
 982                label_df = filtered_df[filtered_df["labels"] == lbl]
 983                label_df["lat"] = label_df["lat"].mean()
 984                label_df["lon"] = label_df["lon"].mean()
 985                label_df = label_df.reset_index()
 986
 987                geometry_df = geometry_df._append(
 988                    label_df[["user_id", "labels", "datetime", "lat", "lon"]],
 989                    ignore_index=True,
 990                )  # type: ignore
 991
 992                # geometry_df = pd.concat([geometry_df, label_df], ignore_index=True)
 993
 994        return TrajectoriesFrame(
 995            geometry_df.sort_values("datetime").drop_duplicates()
 996            )
 997
 998
 999    @staticmethod
1000    def set_start_stop_time(data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> TrajectoriesFrame:
1001        """
1002        Sets the start and stop time for each trajectory point.
1003
1004        Args:
1005            data (TrajectoriesFrame): The input trajectory dataset.
1006
1007        Returns:
1008            TrajectoriesFrame: A dataset with added start and stop times.
1009        """
1010
1011        compressed = pd.DataFrame(
1012            start_end(data).reset_index()[
1013                [
1014                    "user_id",
1015                    "datetime",
1016                    "labels", ""
1017                    "lat",
1018                    "lon",
1019                    "date",
1020                    "start",
1021                    "end"
1022                ]
1023            ]
1024        )
1025
1026        return TrajectoriesFrame(
1027            compressed,
1028            {
1029                "names": ["num", "labels", "lat", "lon", "time", "animal_id"],
1030                "crs": const.ELLIPSOIDAL_CRS,
1031            },
1032        )
1033
1034
1035    @staticmethod
1036    def set_crs(
1037        data: TrajectoriesFrame,
1038        base_csr: int = const.ELLIPSOIDAL_CRS,
1039        target_crs: int = const.CARTESIAN_CRS,
1040    ) -> TrajectoriesFrame:
1041        """
1042        Converts the coordinate reference system (CRS) of the dataset.
1043
1044        Args:
1045            data (TrajectoriesFrame): The input dataset.
1046            base_csr (int): The current CRS of the dataset.
1047            target_crs (int): The target CRS to convert to.
1048
1049        Returns:
1050            TrajectoriesFrame: The dataset with the transformed CRS.
1051        """
1052
1053        data_frame = data.copy().set_crs(base_csr)  # type: ignore
1054
1055        return data_frame.to_crs(target_crs)
1056
1057
1058    @staticmethod
1059    def filter_by_min_number(
1060        data: TrajectoriesFrame, min_labels_no: int = const.MIN_LABEL_NO
1061    ) -> TrajectoriesFrame:
1062        """
1063        Filters data to include only individuals with a minimum
1064        number of labels.
1065
1066        Args:
1067            data (TrajectoriesFrame): The input trajectory dataset.
1068            min_labels_no (int): The minimum number of labels required.
1069
1070        Returns:
1071            TrajectoriesFrame: The filtered dataset.
1072        """
1073
1074        data_without_nans = data[data.isna().any(axis=1)]
1075        distinct_locations = num_of_distinct_locations(data_without_nans)
1076
1077        return TrajectoriesFrame(
1078            data_without_nans.loc[
1079                distinct_locations[distinct_locations > min_labels_no].index
1080            ]
1081        )
1082
1083
1084    @staticmethod
1085    def filter_by_quartiles(
1086        data: TrajectoriesFrame, quartile: float = const.QUARTILE
1087    ) -> TrajectoriesFrame:
1088        """
1089        Filters data based on quartile values of distinct locations.
1090
1091        Args:
1092            data (TrajectoriesFrame): The input dataset.
1093            quartile (float): The quartile value (must be 0.25, 0.5, or 0.75).
1094
1095        Returns:
1096            TrajectoriesFrame: The filtered dataset.
1097
1098        Raises:
1099            ValueError: If the provided quartile value is not one of
1100                the allowed values.
1101        """
1102
1103        allowed_quartiles = {0.25, 0.5, 0.75}
1104        if quartile not in allowed_quartiles:
1105            raise ValueError(
1106                f"Invalid quartile value: {quartile}. "
1107                f"Allowed values are {allowed_quartiles}."
1108            )
1109        else:
1110            data_without_nans = data[~data.isna().any(axis=1)]
1111            distinct_locations = num_of_distinct_locations(data_without_nans)
1112            quartile_value = np.quantile(distinct_locations, quartile)
1113
1114            if quartile_value < const.MIN_QUARTILE_VALUE:
1115                quartile_value = const.MIN_QUARTILE_VALUE
1116
1117            return TrajectoriesFrame(
1118                data_without_nans.loc[
1119                    distinct_locations[distinct_locations > quartile_value].index
1120                ]
1121            )
1122
1123
1124    @staticmethod
1125    def filing_data(data: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
1126        """
1127        Processes trajectory data to fill missing values by selecting
1128        the most visited location.
1129
1130        Args:
1131            data (pd.DataFrame): The input trajectory dataset.
1132
1133        Returns:
1134            pd.DataFrame: A processed dataset with missing values filled.
1135        """
1136
1137        def longest_visited_row(groupa):
1138            """
1139            Returns the row where the individual spent the longest
1140            time in an interval.
1141            """
1142
1143            if groupa.empty:
1144                return pd.Series(dtype=object)
1145
1146            max_label = (
1147                groupa.groupby("labels")["duration"].sum().idxmax()
1148            )
1149            row = groupa[groupa["labels"] == max_label].iloc[0]
1150
1151            return row.T
1152
1153
1154        to_conca = {}
1155        for uid, group in data.groupby(level=0):
1156            group = group[
1157                ~group["datetime"].duplicated()
1158            ]
1159            if len(group.labels.unique()) < 2:
1160                continue
1161            group.set_index(
1162                "datetime", inplace=True
1163            )
1164            group["duration"] = (
1165                group.index.to_series().shift(-1) - group.index
1166            ).dt.total_seconds()
1167            group["next"] = group.labels != group.labels.shift()
1168            group["moved"] = group.next.cumsum()
1169            (group.groupby("moved").duration.sum() / 3600).describe()
1170            group['duration'] = group['duration'].fillna(3600)
1171
1172            group_resampled = group.resample("1h").apply(longest_visited_row).unstack()
1173            if group_resampled.index.nlevels > 1:
1174                group_resampled = group.resample("1h").apply(longest_visited_row)
1175            group_resampled = group_resampled.resample("1h").first()
1176            group_resampled = group_resampled.ffill().bfill()
1177
1178            to_conca[uid] = group_resampled
1179
1180        df = pd.DataFrame(pd.concat(to_conca))
1181        df["is_new"] = df.groupby(level=0, group_keys=False).apply(
1182            lambda x: ~x.labels.duplicated(keep="first")
1183        )
1184        df["new_sum"] = (
1185            df.groupby(level=0).apply(lambda x: x.is_new.cumsum()).droplevel(1)
1186        )
1187
1188        return df

A class containing static methods for preprocessing animal trajectory data.

Prepocessing() 
953    def __init__(self) -> None:
954        """
955        Initializes the Prepocessing class.
956        """
957        pass

Initializes the Prepocessing class.

@staticmethod
def get_mean_points( data: humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame) -> humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame: 
960    @staticmethod
961    def get_mean_points(data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> TrajectoriesFrame:
962        """
963        Computes the mean latitude and longitude for each label.
964
965        Args:
966            data (TrajectoriesFrame): The trajectory dataset.
967
968        Returns:
969            TrajectoriesFrame: A new dataset with averaged locations
970                per label.
971        """
972
973        basic_df = data.reset_index()
974        geometry_df = pd.DataFrame()
975        for an_id, values in tqdm(
976            data.groupby(level=0), total=len(data.groupby(level=0))
977        ):
978            filtered_df = basic_df[basic_df["user_id"] == an_id]
979            lables_pack = sorted(filtered_df["labels"].unique())
980
981            for lbl in lables_pack:
982                label_df = filtered_df[filtered_df["labels"] == lbl]
983                label_df["lat"] = label_df["lat"].mean()
984                label_df["lon"] = label_df["lon"].mean()
985                label_df = label_df.reset_index()
986
987                geometry_df = geometry_df._append(
988                    label_df[["user_id", "labels", "datetime", "lat", "lon"]],
989                    ignore_index=True,
990                )  # type: ignore
991
992                # geometry_df = pd.concat([geometry_df, label_df], ignore_index=True)
993
994        return TrajectoriesFrame(
995            geometry_df.sort_values("datetime").drop_duplicates()
996            )

Computes the mean latitude and longitude for each label.

Args: data (TrajectoriesFrame): The trajectory dataset.

Returns: TrajectoriesFrame: A new dataset with averaged locations per label.

@staticmethod
def set_start_stop_time( data: humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame) -> humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame: 
 999    @staticmethod
1000    def set_start_stop_time(data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> TrajectoriesFrame:
1001        """
1002        Sets the start and stop time for each trajectory point.
1003
1004        Args:
1005            data (TrajectoriesFrame): The input trajectory dataset.
1006
1007        Returns:
1008            TrajectoriesFrame: A dataset with added start and stop times.
1009        """
1010
1011        compressed = pd.DataFrame(
1012            start_end(data).reset_index()[
1013                [
1014                    "user_id",
1015                    "datetime",
1016                    "labels", ""
1017                    "lat",
1018                    "lon",
1019                    "date",
1020                    "start",
1021                    "end"
1022                ]
1023            ]
1024        )
1025
1026        return TrajectoriesFrame(
1027            compressed,
1028            {
1029                "names": ["num", "labels", "lat", "lon", "time", "animal_id"],
1030                "crs": const.ELLIPSOIDAL_CRS,
1031            },
1032        )

Sets the start and stop time for each trajectory point.

Args: data (TrajectoriesFrame): The input trajectory dataset.

Returns: TrajectoriesFrame: A dataset with added start and stop times.

@staticmethod
def set_crs( data: humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame, base_csr: int = 4326, target_crs: int = 3857) -> humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame: 
1035    @staticmethod
1036    def set_crs(
1037        data: TrajectoriesFrame,
1038        base_csr: int = const.ELLIPSOIDAL_CRS,
1039        target_crs: int = const.CARTESIAN_CRS,
1040    ) -> TrajectoriesFrame:
1041        """
1042        Converts the coordinate reference system (CRS) of the dataset.
1043
1044        Args:
1045            data (TrajectoriesFrame): The input dataset.
1046            base_csr (int): The current CRS of the dataset.
1047            target_crs (int): The target CRS to convert to.
1048
1049        Returns:
1050            TrajectoriesFrame: The dataset with the transformed CRS.
1051        """
1052
1053        data_frame = data.copy().set_crs(base_csr)  # type: ignore
1054
1055        return data_frame.to_crs(target_crs)

Converts the coordinate reference system (CRS) of the dataset.

Args: data (TrajectoriesFrame): The input dataset. base_csr (int): The current CRS of the dataset. target_crs (int): The target CRS to convert to.

Returns: TrajectoriesFrame: The dataset with the transformed CRS.

@staticmethod
def filter_by_min_number( data: humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame, min_labels_no: int = 3) -> humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame: 
1058    @staticmethod
1059    def filter_by_min_number(
1060        data: TrajectoriesFrame, min_labels_no: int = const.MIN_LABEL_NO
1061    ) -> TrajectoriesFrame:
1062        """
1063        Filters data to include only individuals with a minimum
1064        number of labels.
1065
1066        Args:
1067            data (TrajectoriesFrame): The input trajectory dataset.
1068            min_labels_no (int): The minimum number of labels required.
1069
1070        Returns:
1071            TrajectoriesFrame: The filtered dataset.
1072        """
1073
1074        data_without_nans = data[data.isna().any(axis=1)]
1075        distinct_locations = num_of_distinct_locations(data_without_nans)
1076
1077        return TrajectoriesFrame(
1078            data_without_nans.loc[
1079                distinct_locations[distinct_locations > min_labels_no].index
1080            ]
1081        )

Filters data to include only individuals with a minimum number of labels.

Args: data (TrajectoriesFrame): The input trajectory dataset. min_labels_no (int): The minimum number of labels required.

Returns: TrajectoriesFrame: The filtered dataset.

@staticmethod
def filter_by_quartiles( data: humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame, quartile: float = 0.25) -> humobi.structures.trajectory.TrajectoriesFrame: 
1084    @staticmethod
1085    def filter_by_quartiles(
1086        data: TrajectoriesFrame, quartile: float = const.QUARTILE
1087    ) -> TrajectoriesFrame:
1088        """
1089        Filters data based on quartile values of distinct locations.
1090
1091        Args:
1092            data (TrajectoriesFrame): The input dataset.
1093            quartile (float): The quartile value (must be 0.25, 0.5, or 0.75).
1094
1095        Returns:
1096            TrajectoriesFrame: The filtered dataset.
1097
1098        Raises:
1099            ValueError: If the provided quartile value is not one of
1100                the allowed values.
1101        """
1102
1103        allowed_quartiles = {0.25, 0.5, 0.75}
1104        if quartile not in allowed_quartiles:
1105            raise ValueError(
1106                f"Invalid quartile value: {quartile}. "
1107                f"Allowed values are {allowed_quartiles}."
1108            )
1109        else:
1110            data_without_nans = data[~data.isna().any(axis=1)]
1111            distinct_locations = num_of_distinct_locations(data_without_nans)
1112            quartile_value = np.quantile(distinct_locations, quartile)
1113
1114            if quartile_value < const.MIN_QUARTILE_VALUE:
1115                quartile_value = const.MIN_QUARTILE_VALUE
1116
1117            return TrajectoriesFrame(
1118                data_without_nans.loc[
1119                    distinct_locations[distinct_locations > quartile_value].index
1120                ]
1121            )

Filters data based on quartile values of distinct locations.

Args: data (TrajectoriesFrame): The input dataset. quartile (float): The quartile value (must be 0.25, 0.5, or 0.75).

Returns: TrajectoriesFrame: The filtered dataset.

Raises: ValueError: If the provided quartile value is not one of the allowed values.

@staticmethod
def filing_data(data: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame) -> pandas.core.frame.DataFrame: 
1124    @staticmethod
1125    def filing_data(data: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
1126        """
1127        Processes trajectory data to fill missing values by selecting
1128        the most visited location.
1129
1130        Args:
1131            data (pd.DataFrame): The input trajectory dataset.
1132
1133        Returns:
1134            pd.DataFrame: A processed dataset with missing values filled.
1135        """
1136
1137        def longest_visited_row(groupa):
1138            """
1139            Returns the row where the individual spent the longest
1140            time in an interval.
1141            """
1142
1143            if groupa.empty:
1144                return pd.Series(dtype=object)
1145
1146            max_label = (
1147                groupa.groupby("labels")["duration"].sum().idxmax()
1148            )
1149            row = groupa[groupa["labels"] == max_label].iloc[0]
1150
1151            return row.T
1152
1153
1154        to_conca = {}
1155        for uid, group in data.groupby(level=0):
1156            group = group[
1157                ~group["datetime"].duplicated()
1158            ]
1159            if len(group.labels.unique()) < 2:
1160                continue
1161            group.set_index(
1162                "datetime", inplace=True
1163            )
1164            group["duration"] = (
1165                group.index.to_series().shift(-1) - group.index
1166            ).dt.total_seconds()
1167            group["next"] = group.labels != group.labels.shift()
1168            group["moved"] = group.next.cumsum()
1169            (group.groupby("moved").duration.sum() / 3600).describe()
1170            group['duration'] = group['duration'].fillna(3600)
1171
1172            group_resampled = group.resample("1h").apply(longest_visited_row).unstack()
1173            if group_resampled.index.nlevels > 1:
1174                group_resampled = group.resample("1h").apply(longest_visited_row)
1175            group_resampled = group_resampled.resample("1h").first()
1176            group_resampled = group_resampled.ffill().bfill()
1177
1178            to_conca[uid] = group_resampled
1179
1180        df = pd.DataFrame(pd.concat(to_conca))
1181        df["is_new"] = df.groupby(level=0, group_keys=False).apply(
1182            lambda x: ~x.labels.duplicated(keep="first")
1183        )
1184        df["new_sum"] = (
1185            df.groupby(level=0).apply(lambda x: x.is_new.cumsum()).droplevel(1)
1186        )
1187
1188        return df

Processes trajectory data to fill missing values by selecting the most visited location.

Args: data (pd.DataFrame): The input trajectory dataset.

Returns: pd.DataFrame: A processed dataset with missing values filled.

class Flexation: 
1192class Flexation:
1193    """
1194    A class used for identifying and fitting statistical distributions to
1195    segmented data based on flexation points.
1196
1197    Flexation points are identified using the PELT (Pruned Exact Linear Time)
1198    change point detection algorithm. Once flexation points are detected,
1199    the data is split into left and right segments, and statistical models
1200    are fitted to each segment. The goodness of fit is evaluated using
1201    the Wasserstein distance between the empirical density and the fitted
1202    model.
1203
1204    Attributes:
1205    -----------
1206    None
1207    """
1208
1209    def __init__(self) -> None:
1210        pass
1211
1212
1213    def _calculate_penalty(self, data:ndarray) -> float:
1214        """
1215        Calculates a penalty value based on the dataset size
1216        and predefined sensitivity settings.
1217
1218        The penalty is determined using logarithmic scaling and
1219        depends on the sensitivity level set
1220        in `const.FLEXATION_POINTS_SENSITIVITY`.
1221
1222        Parameters:
1223        -----------
1224        data : ndarray
1225            The numerical dataset for which the penalty is calculated.
1226
1227        Returns:
1228        --------
1229        float
1230            The computed penalty value based on the selected
1231                sensitivity level.
1232        """
1233        if const.FLEXATION_POINTS_SENSITIVITY == "Low":
1234            return 6 * log(len(data))
1235        elif const.FLEXATION_POINTS_SENSITIVITY == "Medium":
1236            return 3 * log(len(data))
1237        elif const.FLEXATION_POINTS_SENSITIVITY == "High":
1238            return 1.5 * log(len(data))
1239
1240
1241    def _calc_main_model_wasser(
1242        self, model_obj: distfit, data: ndarray, flexation_point: int
1243    ) -> float:
1244        """
1245        Calculates the Wasserstein distance between the empirical density
1246        and the fitted model for data split at a given flexation point.
1247
1248        Parameters:
1249        -----------
1250        model_obj : distfit
1251            A fitted distfit model object used for density estimation.
1252        data : ndarray
1253            The numerical dataset to be analyzed.
1254        flexation_point : int
1255            The point at which the data is split into left and right subsets.
1256
1257        Returns:
1258        --------
1259        float
1260            The Wasserstein distance between the empirical and model densities.
1261        """
1262
1263        left_set = data[data <= flexation_point]
1264        right_set = data[data >= flexation_point]
1265
1266        main_dfit = distfit()
1267
1268        left_main_bins, left_main_empiric_density = main_dfit.density(
1269            X=left_set, bins=len(left_set)
1270        )
1271        right_main_bins, right_main_empiric_density = main_dfit.density(
1272            X=right_set, bins=len(right_set)
1273        )
1274
1275        left_main_model_density = model_obj.model["model"].pdf(left_main_bins)
1276        right_main_model_density = model_obj.model["model"].pdf(right_main_bins)
1277
1278        empiric_density = np.concatenate(
1279            (left_main_empiric_density, right_main_empiric_density)
1280        )
1281        model_density = np.concatenate(
1282            (left_main_model_density, right_main_model_density)
1283        )
1284
1285        return wasserstein_distance(empiric_density, model_density)
1286
1287
1288    def _fit_mixed_models(
1289            self,
1290            data: ndarray,
1291            flexation_points: list
1292        ) -> pd.DataFrame:
1293        """
1294        Fits statistical distributions to data segments split at given
1295        flexation points and evaluates their goodness of fit using
1296        the Wasserstein distance metric.
1297
1298        Parameters:
1299        -----------
1300        data : ndarray
1301            The numerical dataset to be analyzed.
1302        flexation_points : list
1303            A list of points at which the data is split into left
1304                and right subsets.
1305
1306        Returns:
1307        --------
1308        pd.DataFrame
1309            A DataFrame containing:
1310            - 'point': The flexation point.
1311            - 'left_model': Best-fitted distribution name for the left subset.
1312            - 'left_score': Fit score of the left model from distfit.
1313            - 'left_score_calc': Calculated Wasserstein distance for
1314                the left subset.
1315            - 'right_model': Best-fitted distribution name for
1316                the right subset.
1317            - 'right_score': Fit score of the right model from distfit.
1318            - 'right_score_calc': Calculated Wasserstein distance for
1319                the right subset.
1320            - 'overall_score': Combined Wasserstein distance score
1321                for the entire dataset.
1322        """
1323
1324        fitting_results = pd.DataFrame(
1325            columns=[
1326                "point",
1327                "left_model",
1328                "left_score",
1329                "left_score_calc",
1330                "right_model",
1331                "right_score",
1332                "right_score_calc",
1333                "overall_score",
1334            ]
1335        )
1336
1337        for point in flexation_points:
1338            left_set = data[data <= point]
1339            right_set = data[data >= point]
1340
1341            if left_set.size >= 1 and right_set.size >= 3:  # FIXME:
1342                left_model = distfit(
1343                    distr=[
1344                        "norm",
1345                        "expon",
1346                        "pareto",
1347                        "dweibull",
1348                        "t",
1349                        "genextreme",
1350                        "gamma",
1351                        "lognorm",
1352                        "beta",
1353                        "uniform",
1354                        "loggamma",
1355                        "truncexpon",
1356                        "truncnorm",
1357                        "truncpareto",
1358                        "powerlaw",
1359                    ],
1360                    stats="wasserstein",
1361                )
1362                right_model = distfit(
1363                    distr=[
1364                        "norm",
1365                        "expon",
1366                        "pareto",
1367                        "dweibull",
1368                        "t",
1369                        "genextreme",
1370                        "gamma",
1371                        "lognorm",
1372                        "beta",
1373                        "uniform",
1374                        "loggamma",
1375                        "truncexpon",
1376                        "truncnorm",
1377                        "truncpareto",
1378                        "powerlaw",
1379                    ],
1380                    stats="wasserstein",
1381                )
1382
1383                left_model.fit_transform(left_set)
1384                right_model.fit_transform(right_set)
1385
1386                left_dfit = distfit()
1387                left_bins, left_empiric_density = left_dfit.density(
1388                    X=left_set, bins=len(left_set)
1389                )
1390                left_model_density = left_model.model["model"].pdf(left_bins)
1391
1392                right_dfit = distfit()
1393                right_bins, right_empiric_density = right_dfit.density(
1394                    X=right_set, bins=len(right_set)
1395                )
1396                right_model_density = right_model.model["model"].pdf(right_bins)
1397
1398                left_score_calc = wasserstein_distance(
1399                    left_empiric_density, left_model_density
1400                )
1401                right_score_calc = wasserstein_distance(
1402                    right_empiric_density, right_model_density
1403                )
1404
1405                empiric_density = np.concatenate(
1406                    (left_empiric_density, right_empiric_density)
1407                )
1408                model_density = np.concatenate(
1409                    (left_model_density, right_model_density)
1410                )
1411
1412                overall_score = wasserstein_distance(empiric_density, model_density)
1413
1414                fitting_results = fitting_results._append(
1415                    {
1416                        "point": point,  # flexation point
1417                        "left_model": left_model.model["name"],  # left model name
1418                        "left_score": left_model.summary.sort_values("score")[
1419                            "score"
1420                        ].iloc[
1421                            0
1422                        ],  # left model score from distfit
1423                        "left_score_calc": left_score_calc,  # left model score from our calc
1424                        "right_model": right_model.model["name"],  # right model name
1425                        "right_score": right_model.summary.sort_values("score")[  # type: ignore
1426                            "score"
1427                        ].iloc[
1428                            0
1429                        ],  # right model score from distfit
1430                        "right_score_calc": right_score_calc,  # right model score from our calc
1431                        "overall_score": overall_score,  # wasserstein calculated for mix-distribution approach
1432                    },
1433                    ignore_index=True,
1434                )
1435            else:
1436                pass
1437
1438        return fitting_results.sort_values("right_score", ascending=True)
1439
1440
1441    def _find_flexation_points(self, data: ndarray) -> list:
1442        """
1443        Identifies flexation points in the given dataset using the
1444        PELT (Pruned Exact Linear Time) change point detection algorithm.
1445
1446        The function applies the Pelt model with an "rbf" cost
1447        function to detect significant changes in the data distribution.
1448        A penalty value is used to control the sensitivity of change detection,
1449        which is calculated using `_calculate_penalty`.
1450
1451        Parameters:
1452        -----------
1453        data : ndarray
1454            The numerical dataset in which flexation points (change points)
1455                are to be found.
1456
1457        Returns:
1458        --------
1459        list
1460            A list of detected flexation points, represented as values
1461                from the dataset.
1462        """
1463
1464        penalty = self._calculate_penalty(data)
1465        model = rpt.Pelt(model="rbf").fit(data)
1466        break_points_indx = model.predict(pen=penalty)
1467
1468        return [data[i - 1] for i in break_points_indx]
1469
1470
1471    def find_distributions(self, model: distfit, data: ndarray):
1472        """
1473        Identifies the best-fitting distributions for segmented parts of the
1474        dataset based on flexation points.
1475
1476        The function detects flexation points in the data, evaluates fitting
1477        scores, and compares the segmented model's performance to the main
1478        model. If a segmented approach improves the fit, it returns the left
1479        and right distributions along with their respective datasets.
1480
1481        Parameters:
1482        -----------
1483        model : distfit
1484            A pre-fitted `distfit` model used as a reference for comparison.
1485        data : ndarray
1486            The numerical dataset for which distributions
1487                are to be identified.
1488
1489        Returns:
1490        --------
1491        tuple or None
1492            - If segmentation improves the model fit, returns
1493                a tuple containing:
1494                - left_model (distfit): The best-fitting distribution
1495                    for the left segment.
1496                - right_model (distfit): The best-fitting distribution
1497                    for the right segment.
1498                - left_set (ndarray): The left segment of the data.
1499                - right_set (ndarray): The right segment of the data.
1500                - best_point (float): The chosen flexation point that
1501                    defines segmentation.
1502            - If no improvement is found, returns `None`.
1503        """
1504
1505        flexation_points = self._find_flexation_points(data)
1506        fitting_results = self._fit_mixed_models(data, flexation_points)
1507        if fitting_results.shape[0] == 0:
1508            return None
1509        else:
1510            fitting_score = fitting_results["right_score"].iloc[0]
1511            best_point = fitting_results.iloc[0]["point"]
1512
1513            main_model_score = self._calc_main_model_wasser(model, data, best_point)
1514
1515            if main_model_score - fitting_score < 0:
1516                return None
1517            if main_model_score - fitting_score > 0:
1518                left_set = data[data <= best_point]
1519                right_set = data[data >= best_point]
1520
1521                left_model = distfit(
1522                    distr=[
1523                        "norm",
1524                        "expon",
1525                        "pareto",
1526                        "dweibull",
1527                        "t",
1528                        "genextreme",
1529                        "gamma",
1530                        "lognorm",
1531                        "beta",
1532                        "uniform",
1533                        "loggamma",
1534                        "truncexpon",
1535                        "truncnorm",
1536                        "truncpareto",
1537                        "powerlaw",
1538                    ],
1539                    stats="wasserstein",
1540                )
1541                right_model = distfit(
1542                    distr=[
1543                        "norm",
1544                        "expon",
1545                        "pareto",
1546                        "dweibull",
1547                        "t",
1548                        "genextreme",
1549                        "gamma",
1550                        "lognorm",
1551                        "beta",
1552                        "uniform",
1553                        "loggamma",
1554                        "truncexpon",
1555                        "truncnorm",
1556                        "truncpareto",
1557                        "powerlaw",
1558                    ],
1559                    stats="wasserstein",
1560                )
1561
1562                left_model.fit_transform(left_set)
1563                right_model.fit_transform(right_set)
1564
1565                return left_model, right_model, left_set, right_set, best_point

A class used for identifying and fitting statistical distributions to segmented data based on flexation points.

Flexation points are identified using the PELT (Pruned Exact Linear Time) change point detection algorithm. Once flexation points are detected, the data is split into left and right segments, and statistical models are fitted to each segment. The goodness of fit is evaluated using the Wasserstein distance between the empirical density and the fitted model.

Attributes:

None

def find_distributions(self, model: distfit.distfit.distfit, data: numpy.ndarray): 
1471    def find_distributions(self, model: distfit, data: ndarray):
1472        """
1473        Identifies the best-fitting distributions for segmented parts of the
1474        dataset based on flexation points.
1475
1476        The function detects flexation points in the data, evaluates fitting
1477        scores, and compares the segmented model's performance to the main
1478        model. If a segmented approach improves the fit, it returns the left
1479        and right distributions along with their respective datasets.
1480
1481        Parameters:
1482        -----------
1483        model : distfit
1484            A pre-fitted `distfit` model used as a reference for comparison.
1485        data : ndarray
1486            The numerical dataset for which distributions
1487                are to be identified.
1488
1489        Returns:
1490        --------
1491        tuple or None
1492            - If segmentation improves the model fit, returns
1493                a tuple containing:
1494                - left_model (distfit): The best-fitting distribution
1495                    for the left segment.
1496                - right_model (distfit): The best-fitting distribution
1497                    for the right segment.
1498                - left_set (ndarray): The left segment of the data.
1499                - right_set (ndarray): The right segment of the data.
1500                - best_point (float): The chosen flexation point that
1501                    defines segmentation.
1502            - If no improvement is found, returns `None`.
1503        """
1504
1505        flexation_points = self._find_flexation_points(data)
1506        fitting_results = self._fit_mixed_models(data, flexation_points)
1507        if fitting_results.shape[0] == 0:
1508            return None
1509        else:
1510            fitting_score = fitting_results["right_score"].iloc[0]
1511            best_point = fitting_results.iloc[0]["point"]
1512
1513            main_model_score = self._calc_main_model_wasser(model, data, best_point)
1514
1515            if main_model_score - fitting_score < 0:
1516                return None
1517            if main_model_score - fitting_score > 0:
1518                left_set = data[data <= best_point]
1519                right_set = data[data >= best_point]
1520
1521                left_model = distfit(
1522                    distr=[
1523                        "norm",
1524                        "expon",
1525                        "pareto",
1526                        "dweibull",
1527                        "t",
1528                        "genextreme",
1529                        "gamma",
1530                        "lognorm",
1531                        "beta",
1532                        "uniform",
1533                        "loggamma",
1534                        "truncexpon",
1535                        "truncnorm",
1536                        "truncpareto",
1537                        "powerlaw",
1538                    ],
1539                    stats="wasserstein",
1540                )
1541                right_model = distfit(
1542                    distr=[
1543                        "norm",
1544                        "expon",
1545                        "pareto",
1546                        "dweibull",
1547                        "t",
1548                        "genextreme",
1549                        "gamma",
1550                        "lognorm",
1551                        "beta",
1552                        "uniform",
1553                        "loggamma",
1554                        "truncexpon",
1555                        "truncnorm",
1556                        "truncpareto",
1557                        "powerlaw",
1558                    ],
1559                    stats="wasserstein",
1560                )
1561
1562                left_model.fit_transform(left_set)
1563                right_model.fit_transform(right_set)
1564
1565                return left_model, right_model, left_set, right_set, best_point

Identifies the best-fitting distributions for segmented parts of the dataset based on flexation points.

The function detects flexation points in the data, evaluates fitting scores, and compares the segmented model's performance to the main model. If a segmented approach improves the fit, it returns the left and right distributions along with their respective datasets.

Parameters:

model : distfit A pre-fitted distfit model used as a reference for comparison. data : ndarray The numerical dataset for which distributions are to be identified.

Returns:

tuple or None - If segmentation improves the model fit, returns a tuple containing: - left_model (distfit): The best-fitting distribution for the left segment. - right_model (distfit): The best-fitting distribution for the right segment. - left_set (ndarray): The left segment of the data. - right_set (ndarray): The right segment of the data. - best_point (float): The chosen flexation point that defines segmentation. - If no improvement is found, returns None.

class Laws: 
1569class Laws:
1570    """
1571    A class for handling statistical data analysis and generating
1572    reports in PDF format.
1573
1574    This class takes in a dataset, performs statistical analysis,
1575    applies curve fitting techniques, and generates a PDF report
1576    summarizing the results.
1577
1578    Parameters:
1579    -----------
1580    pdf_object : FPDF
1581        An instance of the `FPDF` class used for generating the
1582            PDF report.
1583    stats_frame : DataSetStats
1584        An instance of `DataSetStats` containing statistical
1585            information about the dataset.
1586    output_path : str
1587        The file path where the generated PDF report will be saved.
1588
1589    Attributes:
1590    -----------
1591    pdf_object : FPDF
1592        The PDF object used for report generation.
1593    output_path : str
1594        The location where the final report will be stored.
1595    stats_frame : DataSetStats
1596        The dataset statistics object containing calculated metrics.
1597    curve_fitting : DistributionFitingTools
1598        A toolset for fitting distributions to the dataset.
1599    """
1600
1601    def __init__(
1602            self,
1603            pdf_object: FPDF,
1604            stats_frame: DataSetStats,
1605            output_path: str
1606        ):
1607        """
1608        Parameters:
1609        -----------
1610        pdf_object : FPDF
1611            An instance of the `FPDF` class used for generating the
1612                PDF report.
1613        stats_frame : DataSetStats
1614            An instance of `DataSetStats` containing statistical
1615                information about the dataset.
1616        output_path : str
1617            The file path where the generated PDF report will be saved.
1618        """
1619
1620        self.pdf_object = pdf_object
1621        self.output_path = output_path
1622        self.stats_frame = stats_frame
1623        self.curve_fitting = DistributionFitingTools()
1624
1625    def _add_pdf_cell(self, txt_to_add: str) -> None:
1626        """
1627        Add a single line of text to the PDF.
1628
1629        Parameters
1630        ----------
1631        txt_to_add : str
1632            Text to be added to the PDF document.
1633        """
1634
1635        self.pdf_object.cell(200, 5, text=txt_to_add, ln=True, align="L")
1636
1637
1638    def _add_pdf_plot(
1639        self,
1640        plot_obj: BytesIO,
1641        image_width: int,
1642        image_height: int,
1643        x_position: float = 10,
1644        y_position: float = None,
1645    ) -> None:
1646        """
1647        Add a plot to the PDF.
1648
1649        Parameters
1650        ----------
1651        plot_obj : BytesIO
1652            A BytesIO object containing the plot image.
1653        image_width : int
1654            Width of the plot in the PDF.
1655        image_height : int
1656            Height of the plot in the PDF.
1657        x_position : int, optional
1658            X-coordinate position of the plot, by default 10.
1659        """
1660
1661        if y_position == None:
1662            y_position = self.pdf_object.get_y()
1663        else:
1664            y_position = y_position
1665
1666        try:
1667            self.pdf_object.image(
1668                plot_obj, x=x_position, y=y_position, w=image_width, h=image_height
1669            )
1670            self.pdf_object.set_y(y_position + image_height + 10)
1671            plot_obj.close()
1672        except Exception as e:
1673            raise RuntimeError(f"Failed to add plot to PDF: {e}")
1674
1675
1676    def _add_pdf_curves_table(self, data:pd.DataFrame, x_offset=10, y_offset=None):
1677        """
1678        Adds a table to the PDF summarizing fitted curve parameters.
1679
1680        The table includes curve names, their weights, and parameters.
1681
1682        Parameters:
1683        -----------
1684        data : pd.DataFrame
1685            A DataFrame containing the curve fitting results with columns:
1686            - "curve" (str): Name of the fitted curve.
1687            - "weight" (float): Weight assigned to the curve.
1688            - "param1" (float): First parameter of the curve.
1689            - "param2" (float): Second parameter of the curve.
1690        x_offset : int, optional
1691            The horizontal offset for table placement in the PDF
1692                (default is 10).
1693        y_offset : int, optional
1694            The vertical offset for table placement. If None,
1695                it uses the current Y position.
1696        """
1697
1698        if y_offset == None:
1699            y_offset = self.pdf_object.get_y()
1700        else:
1701            y_offset = y_offset
1702        self.pdf_object.set_xy(x_offset, y_offset)
1703
1704        self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", size=7)
1705        col_width = 25
1706        self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", style="B", size=6)
1707        self.pdf_object.cell(col_width, 3, "Curve", border="TB", align="C")
1708        self.pdf_object.cell(col_width, 3, "Weight", border="TB", align="C")
1709        self.pdf_object.cell(col_width, 3, "Param 1", border="TB", align="C")
1710        self.pdf_object.cell(col_width, 3, "Param 2", border="TB", align="C")
1711        self.pdf_object.ln()
1712        self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", size=6)
1713
1714        for index, row in data.iterrows():
1715            self.pdf_object.cell(col_width, 3, row["curve"], border=0, align="C")
1716            self.pdf_object.cell(
1717                col_width, 3, str(round(row["weight"], 10)), border=0, align="C"
1718            )
1719            self.pdf_object.cell(
1720                col_width, 3, str(round(row["param1"], 10)), border=0, align="C"
1721            )
1722            self.pdf_object.cell(
1723                col_width, 3, str(round(row["param2"], 10)), border=0, align="C"
1724            )
1725            self.pdf_object.ln()
1726
1727        self.pdf_object.cell(col_width * 4, 0, "", border="T")
1728        self.pdf_object.ln(1)
1729
1730
1731    def _add_pdf_msd_split_table(self, data:pd.DataFrame, x_offset:int=10, y_offset=None):
1732        """
1733        Adds a table to the PDF displaying MSD split analysis.
1734
1735        The table includes ranges of Radius of Gyration (RoG)
1736        and associated curve parameters.
1737
1738        Parameters:
1739        -----------
1740        data : pd.DataFrame
1741            A DataFrame containing MSD split results with columns:
1742            - "RoG range [km]" (str): The range of RoG values.
1743            - "curve" (str): Name of the fitted curve.
1744            - "param1" (float): First parameter of the curve.
1745            - "param2" (float): Second parameter of the curve.
1746        x_offset : int, optional
1747            The horizontal offset for table placement in the
1748                PDF (default is 10).
1749        y_offset : int, optional
1750            The vertical offset for table placement.
1751                If None, it uses the current Y position.
1752        """
1753
1754        if y_offset == None:
1755            y_offset = self.pdf_object.get_y()
1756        else:
1757            y_offset = y_offset
1758        self.pdf_object.set_xy(x_offset, y_offset)
1759
1760        self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", size=7)
1761        col_width = 25
1762        self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", style="B", size=6)
1763        self.pdf_object.cell(col_width, 3, "RoG range [km]", border="TB", align="C")
1764        self.pdf_object.cell(col_width, 3, "Curve", border="TB", align="C")
1765        self.pdf_object.cell(col_width, 3, "Param 1", border="TB", align="C")
1766        self.pdf_object.cell(col_width, 3, "Param 2", border="TB", align="C")
1767        self.pdf_object.ln()
1768        self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", size=6)
1769
1770        for index, row in data.iterrows():
1771            self.pdf_object.cell(
1772                col_width, 3, row["RoG range [km]"], border=0, align="C"
1773            )
1774            self.pdf_object.cell(col_width, 3, row["curve"], border=0, align="C")
1775            self.pdf_object.cell(
1776                col_width, 3, str(round(row["param1"], 10)), border=0, align="C"
1777            )
1778            self.pdf_object.cell(
1779                col_width, 3, str(round(row["param2"], 10)), border=0, align="C"
1780            )
1781            self.pdf_object.ln()
1782
1783        self.pdf_object.cell(col_width * 4, 0, "", border="T")
1784        self.pdf_object.ln(1)
1785
1786
1787    def _add_pdf_distribution_table(self, data):
1788        """
1789        Adds a table to the PDF displaying distribution fitting results.
1790
1791        The table includes distribution names, scores, and fitted parameters.
1792
1793        Parameters:
1794        -----------
1795        data : pd.DataFrame
1796            A DataFrame containing distribution fitting results with columns:
1797            - "name" (str): Name of the fitted distribution.
1798            - "score" (float): Score associated with the fitted distribution.
1799            - "params" (tuple of float): Fitted parameters for
1800                the distribution.
1801        """
1802
1803        self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", style="B", size=6)
1804        self.pdf_object.cell(35, 3, "Distribution", border="TB", align="C")
1805        self.pdf_object.cell(50, 3, "Score", border="TB", align="C")
1806        self.pdf_object.cell(100, 3, "Params", border="TB", align="C")
1807        self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", size=6)
1808        self.pdf_object.ln()
1809
1810        for index, row in data.iterrows():
1811            try:
1812                self.pdf_object.cell(35, 3, row["name"], border=0, align="C")
1813                self.pdf_object.cell(
1814                    50, 3, str(round(row["score"], 15)), border=0, align="C"
1815                )
1816                self.pdf_object.cell(
1817                    100,
1818                    3,
1819                    str(tuple(round(x, 5) for x in row["params"]))
1820                    .replace("(", "")
1821                    .replace(")", ""),
1822                    border=0,
1823                    align="C",
1824                )
1825                # self.pdf_object.cell(40, 5, str(row["params"]), border=1, align="C")
1826                self.pdf_object.ln()
1827            except:
1828                pass
1829        self.pdf_object.cell(185, 0, "", border="T")
1830        self.pdf_object.ln(1)
1831
1832
1833    def _plot_curve(self, func_name, plot_data, y_pred, labels, exp_y_pred=None):
1834        """
1835        Plots a fitted curve along with the original data
1836        and saves it as a PNG file.
1837
1838        Parameters:
1839        -----------
1840        func_name : str
1841            The name of the function, used for saving the file.
1842        plot_data : pd.Series or pd.DataFrame
1843            The original data points to be plotted as scatter points.
1844        y_pred : np.ndarray
1845            The predicted values for the fitted curve.
1846        labels : list of str
1847            A list containing x-axis and y-axis labels.
1848        exp_y_pred : np.ndarray, optional
1849            If provided, an additional exponential curve is plotted.
1850
1851        Returns:
1852        --------
1853        BytesIO
1854            A buffer containing the saved image.
1855        """
1856
1857        buffer = BytesIO()
1858
1859        sns.set_style("whitegrid")
1860        plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4.5))
1861
1862        if exp_y_pred is not None and exp_y_pred.size > 0:
1863            plt.plot(plot_data.index, y_pred, c="k", linestyle="--", label="Sigmoid")
1864            plt.plot(
1865                plot_data.index, exp_y_pred, c="r", linestyle="-.", label="Expon neg"
1866            )
1867
1868        else:
1869            plt.plot(
1870                plot_data.index, y_pred, c="k", linestyle="--", label="Fitted curve"
1871            )
1872
1873        plt.scatter(plot_data.index, plot_data, color="darkturquoise", label="Data")
1874        plt.xscale("log")
1875        plt.yscale("log")
1876        plt.xlabel(labels[0], fontsize=12)
1877        plt.ylabel(labels[1], fontsize=12)
1878        plt.legend(loc="lower left", frameon=True, fontsize=10)
1879        plt.grid(True, which="both", linestyle="--", linewidth=0.5)
1880        plt.loglog()
1881        plt.savefig(
1882            os.path.join(
1883                self.output_path,
1884                f"{func_name}.png",
1885            )
1886        )
1887        plt.savefig(buffer, format="png")
1888        plt.close()
1889        buffer.seek(0)
1890
1891        return buffer
1892
1893
1894    def _plot_distribution(self, model, values, measure_type: str = "Values"):
1895        """
1896        Plots a histogram of values and a fitted probability distribution model.
1897
1898        Parameters:
1899        -----------
1900        model : distfit
1901            A fitted distribution model.
1902        values : np.ndarray
1903            The dataset values to be plotted.
1904        measure_type : str, optional
1905            The type of measure for labeling the x-axis (default is "Values").
1906
1907        Returns:
1908        --------
1909        tuple (BytesIO, BytesIO)
1910            Buffers containing the saved histogram and fitted model plots.
1911        """
1912
1913        buffer_plot_distribution = BytesIO()
1914        buffer_plot_model = BytesIO()
1915
1916        measure_type = (
1917            measure_type.replace("_", " ").replace("distribution", "").capitalize()
1918        )
1919
1920        sns.set_style("whitegrid")
1921        plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))
1922        plt.hist(values, color="darkturquoise", bins=100, density=True)
1923        plt.xlabel(measure_type)
1924        plt.ylabel("Values")
1925        plt.loglog()
1926
1927        plt.savefig(
1928            os.path.join(
1929                self.output_path,
1930                f"{measure_type}_distribution.png",
1931            )
1932        )
1933        plt.savefig(buffer_plot_distribution, format="png")
1934        plt.close()
1935        buffer_plot_distribution.seek(0)
1936
1937        plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))
1938        model.plot(
1939            pdf_properties={"color": "black", "linewidth": 2, "linestyle": "--"},
1940            bar_properties=None,
1941            cii_properties=None,
1942            emp_properties={"color": "darkturquoise", "linewidth": 0, "marker": "o"},
1943            figsize=(8, 6),
1944        )
1945        plt.xlabel(measure_type)
1946        plt.loglog()
1947
1948        plt.savefig(
1949            os.path.join(
1950                self.output_path,
1951                f"{measure_type}_model_distribution.png",
1952            )
1953        )
1954        plt.savefig(buffer_plot_model, format="png")
1955        plt.close()
1956        buffer_plot_model.seek(0)
1957
1958        return buffer_plot_distribution, buffer_plot_model
1959
1960
1961    def _plot_double_distribution(
1962        self,
1963        left_model,
1964        right_model,
1965        left_values,
1966        right_values,
1967        flexation_point,
1968        measure_type: str = "Values",
1969    ):
1970        """
1971        Plots and saves histograms for two subsets of data
1972        and their fitted distribution models.
1973
1974        Parameters:
1975        -----------
1976        left_model : distfit
1977            A fitted distribution model for the left subset.
1978        right_model : distfit
1979            A fitted distribution model for the right subset.
1980        left_values : np.ndarray
1981            The left subset of data values.
1982        right_values : np.ndarray
1983            The right subset of data values.
1984        flexation_point : float
1985            The point at which the data was split.
1986        measure_type : str, optional
1987            The type of measure for labeling the x-axis
1988                (default is "Values").
1989
1990        Returns:
1991        --------
1992        tuple (BytesIO, BytesIO)
1993            Buffers containing the saved histograms and model plots.
1994        """
1995
1996        measure_type = (
1997            measure_type.replace("_", " ").replace("distribution", "").capitalize()
1998        )
1999
2000        buffer_plot_distribution = BytesIO()
2001        buffer_plot_model = BytesIO()
2002
2003        sns.set_style("whitegrid")
2004
2005        plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))
2006        plt.hist(
2007            left_values,
2008            bins=50,
2009            density=True,
2010            label="Left Set",
2011            color="grey",
2012        )
2013        plt.hist(
2014            right_values,
2015            bins=50,
2016            density=True,
2017            label="Right Set",
2018            color="darkturquoise",
2019        )
2020        plt.loglog()
2021        plt.xlabel(measure_type)
2022        plt.ylabel("Values")
2023        plt.savefig(
2024            os.path.join(
2025                self.output_path,
2026                f"{measure_type}_distribution_with_flexation_point_{flexation_point}.png",
2027            )
2028        )
2029        plt.savefig(buffer_plot_distribution, format="png")
2030        plt.close()
2031        buffer_plot_distribution.seek(0)
2032
2033        left_model.plot(
2034            pdf_properties={"color": "black", "linewidth": 2, "linestyle": "--"},
2035            bar_properties=None,
2036            cii_properties=None,
2037            emp_properties={"color": "darkturquoise", "linewidth": 0, "marker": "o"},
2038            figsize=(8, 6),
2039        )
2040
2041        right_model.plot(
2042            pdf_properties={"color": "black", "linewidth": 2, "linestyle": "--"},
2043            bar_properties=None,
2044            cii_properties=None,
2045            emp_properties={"color": "darkturquoise", "linewidth": 0, "marker": "o"},
2046            figsize=(8, 6),
2047        )
2048
2049        plt.legend()
2050        plt.grid()
2051        plt.loglog()
2052        plt.savefig(
2053            os.path.join(
2054                self.output_path,
2055                f"{measure_type}_model_distribution_with_flexation_point_{flexation_point}.png",
2056            )
2057        )
2058        plt.savefig(buffer_plot_model, format="png")
2059        plt.close()
2060        buffer_plot_model.seek(0)
2061
2062        return buffer_plot_distribution, buffer_plot_model
2063
2064
2065    def _plot_P_new(
2066        self, rho_est, gamma_est, DeltaS, S_mid, intercept, slope, nrows, n_data
2067    ):
2068        """
2069        Plots and saves two figures:
2070        1. A comparison between estimated and reference probability functions.
2071        2. A log-log plot of ΔS vs. S with a fitted regression line.
2072
2073        Parameters:
2074        -----------
2075        rho_est : float
2076            Estimated scaling factor for P_new.
2077        gamma_est : float
2078            Estimated exponent for P_new.
2079        DeltaS : np.ndarray
2080            Change in S values for log-log regression.
2081        S_mid : np.ndarray
2082            Midpoints of S values for log-log regression.
2083        intercept : float
2084            Intercept of the fitted regression line in log-log plot.
2085        slope : float
2086            Slope of the fitted regression line in log-log plot.
2087        nrows : int
2088            Number of time steps for P_new estimation.
2089        n_data : int
2090            Number of data points in the dataset.
2091
2092        Returns:
2093        --------
2094        tuple (BytesIO, BytesIO)
2095            Buffers containing the saved plots.
2096        """
2097
2098        buffer1 = BytesIO()
2099        sns.set_style("whitegrid")
2100        plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4.5))
2101        plt.plot(
2102            np.arange(1, nrows),
2103            [rho_est * x ** (-gamma_est) for x in range(1, nrows)],
2104            label="Estimated",
2105            color="darkturquoise",
2106        )
2107        plt.plot(
2108            np.arange(1, nrows),
2109            [0.6 * x ** (-0.21) for x in range(1, nrows)],
2110            label="Paper",
2111            color="black",
2112        )
2113        plt.legend()
2114        plt.xlabel("Time steps (n)")
2115        plt.ylabel("P_new (estimated vs. reference)")
2116        plt.title("Comparison of Estimated vs. Paper Model")
2117        plt.savefig(
2118            os.path.join(
2119                self.output_path,
2120                "P new comparison of Estimated vs. Paper Model.png",
2121            )
2122        )
2123        plt.savefig(buffer1, format="png")
2124        plt.close()
2125        buffer1.seek(0)
2126
2127        buffer2 = BytesIO()
2128        sns.set_style("whitegrid")
2129        plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4.5))
2130        plt.plot(
2131            np.log(S_mid),
2132            np.log(DeltaS),
2133            "o",
2134            label="Data (log-log)",
2135            color="darkturquoise",
2136        )
2137        X_line = np.linspace(np.log(min(S_mid)), np.log(max(S_mid)), 100)
2138        y_line = intercept + slope * X_line
2139        plt.plot(X_line, y_line, "--", label="Fit", color="black")
2140        plt.xlabel("ln(S)")
2141        plt.ylabel("ln(ΔS)")
2142        plt.title("log(ΔS) vs. log(S)")
2143        plt.legend()
2144        plt.savefig(
2145            os.path.join(
2146                self.output_path,
2147                "P_loglog.png",
2148            )
2149        )
2150        plt.savefig(buffer2, format="png")
2151        plt.close()
2152        buffer2.seek(0)
2153
2154        return buffer1, buffer2
2155
2156
2157    def log_curve_fitting_resluts(func):
2158        """
2159        A decorator that logs and saves curve fitting results
2160        to a PDF report.
2161
2162        The decorated function is expected to return:
2163        - func_name (str): Name of the function.
2164        - best_fit (str): Name of the best-fitting curve.
2165        - param_frame (pd.DataFrame): DataFrame containing
2166            curve parameters.
2167        - plot_obj (BytesIO): The plot image object.
2168
2169        The results are logged in `self.stats_frame`
2170            and added to a PDF report.
2171
2172        Parameters:
2173        -----------
2174        func : function
2175            The function performing curve fitting.
2176
2177        Returns:
2178        --------
2179        function
2180            Wrapped function with additional logging and PDF output.
2181        """
2182
2183        def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
2184            func_name, best_fit, param_frame, plot_obj = func(self, *args, **kwargs)
2185            filtered_df = param_frame[param_frame["curve"] == best_fit]
2186
2187            self.stats_frame.add_data({func_name: best_fit})
2188            self.stats_frame.add_data(
2189                {
2190                    f"{func_name}_params": filtered_df[
2191                        ["param1", "param2"]
2192                    ].values.tolist()
2193                }
2194            )
2195
2196            func_name = func_name.replace("_", " ").split(" ")
2197            func_name[0] = func_name[0].capitalize()
2198            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", "B", size=8)
2199            self._add_pdf_cell(f"{' '.join(func_name)}")
2200            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", size=7)
2201            self._add_pdf_cell(
2202                f'Best fit: {best_fit} with Param 1: {filtered_df["param1"].values[0]},'
2203                f'Param 2: {filtered_df["param2"].values[0]}'
2204            )
2205
2206            y_position_global = float(self.pdf_object.get_y())
2207            self._add_pdf_curves_table(
2208                param_frame, x_offset=10, y_offset=y_position_global + 13
2209            )
2210            self._add_pdf_plot(
2211                plot_obj=plot_obj,
2212                image_width=80,
2213                image_height=45,
2214                x_position=125,
2215                y_position=y_position_global,
2216            )
2217
2218        return wrapper
2219
2220
2221    def log_distribution_fitting_resluts(func):
2222        """
2223        A decorator that logs and saves distribution fitting
2224        results to a PDF report.
2225
2226        The decorated function is expected to return:
2227        - results[0] (str): The name of the fitted distribution.
2228        - results[1] (distfit object): Fitted distribution model.
2229        - results[2] (BytesIO): Distribution plot.
2230        - results[3] (BytesIO): Model plot.
2231        - results[4] (tuple, optional): If present, contains
2232            information about a flexion point.
2233
2234        If a flexion point is detected, it logs both left
2235        and right distributions and plots them separately.
2236
2237        Parameters:
2238        -----------
2239        func : function
2240            The function performing distribution fitting.
2241
2242        Returns:
2243        --------
2244        function
2245            Wrapped function with additional logging and PDF output.
2246        """
2247
2248        def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
2249            results = func(self, *args, **kwargs)
2250
2251            self.stats_frame.add_data({results[0]: results[1].model["name"]})
2252            self.stats_frame.add_data(
2253                {f"{results[0]}_params": results[1].model["params"]}
2254            )
2255
2256            func_name = results[0].replace("_", " ").split(" ")
2257            func_name[0] = func_name[0].capitalize()
2258            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", "B", size=8)
2259            self._add_pdf_cell(f"{' '.join(func_name)}")
2260            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", size=7)
2261            self._add_pdf_cell(
2262                f'Best fit: {results[1].model["name"]} with params: {results[1].model["params"]}'
2263            )
2264
2265            self._add_pdf_distribution_table(
2266                results[1].summary[["name", "score", "params"]]
2267            )
2268            y_position_global = float(self.pdf_object.get_y())
2269            self._add_pdf_plot(
2270                results[2], 80, 60, x_position=10, y_position=y_position_global
2271            )
2272            self._add_pdf_plot(
2273                results[3], 80, 60, x_position=110, y_position=y_position_global
2274            )
2275
2276            if len(results) == 5:
2277                self._add_pdf_cell(
2278                    f"At point {results[4][4]}, the flexion point of the distributions was found"
2279                )
2280                self._add_pdf_cell(
2281                    f'Left distribution is {results[4][0].model["name"]} with params: {results[4][0].model["params"]}'
2282                )
2283                self._add_pdf_cell(
2284                    f'Right distribution is {results[4][1].model["name"]} with params: {results[4][1].model["params"]}'
2285                )
2286                self._add_pdf_distribution_table(
2287                    results[4][1].summary[["name", "score", "params"]]
2288                )
2289                plot_distribution, plot_models = self._plot_double_distribution(
