2290                    results[4][0],
2291                    results[4][1],
2292                    results[4][2],
2293                    results[4][3],
2294                    results[4][4],
2295                    results[0],
2296                )
2297                y_position_global = float(self.pdf_object.get_y())
2298                self._add_pdf_plot(
2299                    plot_distribution,
2300                    80,
2301                    60,
2302                    x_position=10,
2303                    y_position=y_position_global,
2304                )
2305                self._add_pdf_plot(
2306                    plot_models, 80, 60, x_position=110, y_position=y_position_global
2307                )
2308            self.pdf_object.add_page()
2309
2310        return wrapper
2311
2312
2313    def log_pnew_estimation(func):
2314        """
2315        A decorator that logs and saves P_new estimation results
2316        to a PDF report.
2317
2318        The decorated function is expected to return:
2319        - rho_est (float): Estimated rho parameter.
2320        - gamma_est (float): Estimated gamma parameter.
2321        - DeltaS (np.ndarray): Change in S values for log-log regression.
2322        - S_mid (np.ndarray): Midpoints of S values for log-log regression.
2323        - intercept (float): Intercept of the fitted regression line.
2324        - slope (float): Slope of the fitted regression line.
2325        - nrows (int): Number of time steps for estimation.
2326        - n_data (int): Number of data points.
2327
2328        The results are logged in `self.stats_frame`
2329        and visualized in a PDF.
2330
2331        Parameters:
2332        -----------
2333        func : function
2334            The function performing P_new estimation.
2335
2336        Returns:
2337        --------
2338        function
2339            Wrapped function with additional logging and PDF output.
2340        """
2341
2342        def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
2343            rho_est, gamma_est, DeltaS, S_mid, intercept, slope, nrows, n_data = func(
2344                self, *args, **kwargs
2345            )  # type: ignore
2346
2347            self.stats_frame.add_data({"rho": rho_est})
2348            self.stats_frame.add_data({"gamma": gamma_est})
2349
2350            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", "B", size=8)
2351            self._add_pdf_cell("Pnew estimation")
2352
2353            self.pdf_object.ln()
2354            self.pdf_object.ln()
2355            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", size=7)
2356            self._add_pdf_cell(f"gamma  = {gamma_est:.4f}")
2357            self._add_pdf_cell(f"rho  = {rho_est:.4f}")
2358            y_position_global = float(self.pdf_object.get_y())
2359            plot_obj1, plot_obj2 = self._plot_P_new(
2360                rho_est, gamma_est, DeltaS, S_mid, intercept, slope, nrows, n_data
2361            )
2362            self._add_pdf_plot(
2363                plot_obj=plot_obj1,
2364                image_width=80,
2365                image_height=45,
2366                x_position=10,
2367                y_position=y_position_global,
2368            )
2369            self._add_pdf_plot(
2370                plot_obj=plot_obj2,
2371                image_width=80,
2372                image_height=45,
2373                x_position=110,
2374                y_position=y_position_global,
2375            )
2376
2377        return wrapper
2378
2379
2380    def log_msd_split(func):
2381        """
2382        A decorator that logs and saves MSD split results
2383        to a PDF report.
2384
2385        The decorated function is expected to return:
2386        - msd_results (pd.DataFrame): MSD split results
2387            including range and curve parameters.
2388        - plot_obj (BytesIO): The plot image object.
2389
2390        The results are stored in `self.stats_frame`
2391        and included in a PDF report.
2392
2393        Parameters:
2394        -----------
2395        func : function
2396            The function performing MSD split analysis.
2397
2398        Returns:
2399        --------
2400        function
2401            Wrapped function with additional logging and PDF output.
2402        """
2403
2404        def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
2405            msd_results, plot_obj = func(self, *args, **kwargs)  # type: ignore
2406            msd_curve = "; ".join(
2407                msd_results["RoG range [km]"] + ": " + msd_results["curve"]
2408            )
2409            msd_curve_params = "; ".join(
2410                msd_results["RoG range [km]"]
2411                + "("
2412                + msd_results["curve"]
2413                + ")"
2414                + ":"
2415                + msd_results["param1"].astype(str)
2416                + ","
2417                + msd_results["param2"].astype(str)
2418            )
2419
2420            self.stats_frame.add_data({"msd_curve": msd_curve})
2421            self.stats_frame.add_data({"msd_curve_params": msd_curve_params})
2422
2423            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", "B", size=8)
2424            self._add_pdf_cell("MSD split")
2425            y_position_global = float(self.pdf_object.get_y())
2426            self.pdf_object.ln(4)
2427            self._add_pdf_msd_split_table(msd_results)
2428            self._add_pdf_plot(
2429                plot_obj=plot_obj,
2430                image_width=80,
2431                image_height=45,
2432                x_position=125,
2433                y_position=y_position_global,
2434            )
2435
2436        return wrapper
2437
2438
2439    def check_curve_fit(func):
2440        """
2441        A decorator that evaluates curve fitting results
2442        and generates a corresponding plot.
2443
2444        The decorated function is expected to return:
2445        - best_fit (str): Name of the best-fitting curve.
2446        - param_frame (pd.DataFrame): DataFrame containing
2447            curve parameters.
2448        - y_pred (np.ndarray): Predicted values based on
2449            the curve fitting.
2450        - exp_y_pred (np.ndarray or None): Exponential
2451            curve prediction (if applicable).
2452        - plot_data (pd.Series or np.ndarray): Data used for fitting.
2453        - labels (list): Axis labels for the plot.
2454
2455        If `best_fit` is not among {"linear", "expon", "expon_neg"},
2456        both the fitted curve and an additional exponential curve
2457        are plotted. Otherwise, only the fitted curve is plotted.
2458
2459        Parameters:
2460        -----------
2461        func : function
2462            The function performing curve fitting.
2463
2464        Returns:
2465        --------
2466        function
2467            Wrapped function that returns:
2468            - func.__name__ (str): Name of the function.
2469            - best_fit (str): Best fitting curve name.
2470            - param_frame (pd.DataFrame): Parameters of
2471                the best fit.
2472            - plot_obj (BytesIO): Image object containing
2473                the generated plot.
2474        """
2475
2476        def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
2477            best_fit, param_frame, y_pred, exp_y_pred, plot_data, labels = func(
2478                self, *args, **kwargs
2479            )  # type: ignore
2480            if best_fit not in {"linear", "expon", "expon_neg"}:
2481                plot_obj = self._plot_curve(
2482                    func.__name__, plot_data, y_pred, labels, exp_y_pred
2483                )
2484                return func.__name__, best_fit, param_frame, plot_obj
2485            else:
2486                plot_obj = self._plot_curve(func.__name__, plot_data, y_pred, labels)
2487                return func.__name__, best_fit, param_frame, plot_obj
2488
2489        return wrapper
2490
2491
2492    def check_distribution_fit(func):
2493        """
2494        A decorator that evaluates the results of distribution
2495        fitting and detects flexation points.
2496
2497        The decorated function is expected to return:
2498        - model (distfit object): The best-fitted distribution
2499            model.
2500        - data (pd.Series or np.ndarray): Data used for
2501            distribution fitting.
2502
2503        The function generates:
2504        - A histogram plot of the fitted distribution.
2505        - A model plot displaying the probability density function (PDF).
2506
2507        If the fitted distribution is not in `const.DISTRIBUTIONS`
2508        and the data has at least 4 observations, or if specific conditions
2509        apply (e.g., Pareto or Lognormal with parameter > 2),
2510        an attempt is made to detect flexation points in the distribution.
2511
2512        Parameters:
2513        -----------
2514        func : function
2515            The function performing distribution fitting.
2516
2517        Returns:
2518        --------
2519        function
2520            Wrapped function that returns:
2521            - func.__name__ (str): Name of the function.
2522            - model (distfit object): Best-fitting distribution model.
2523            - plot_distribution_obj (BytesIO): Image object containing
2524                the histogram plot.
2525            - plot_model_obj (BytesIO): Image object containing the PDF plot.
2526            - flexation_point_detection_results (tuple, optional):
2527            If flexation points are found, returns details of left
2528            and right distributions.
2529        """
2530
2531        def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
2532            model, data = func(self, *args, **kwargs)
2533
2534            plot_distribution_obj, plot_model_obj = self._plot_distribution(
2535                model, data, func.__name__
2536            )
2537            if (
2538                model.model["name"] not in const.DISTRIBUTIONS and data.shape[0] >= 4
2539            ):  # FIXME:
2540                flexation_point_detection_results = Flexation().find_distributions(
2541                    model, np.sort(data.values)
2542                )
2543                if flexation_point_detection_results != None:
2544
2545                    return (
2546                        func.__name__,
2547                        model,
2548                        plot_distribution_obj,
2549                        plot_model_obj,
2550                        flexation_point_detection_results,
2551                    )
2552                else:
2553                    return func.__name__, model, plot_distribution_obj, plot_model_obj
2554            elif model.model["name"] == "pareto" and model.model["params"][0] > 2:
2555                flexation_point_detection_results = Flexation().find_distributions(
2556                    model, np.sort(data.values)
2557                )
2558                if flexation_point_detection_results != None:
2559
2560                    return (
2561                        func.__name__,
2562                        model,
2563                        plot_distribution_obj,
2564                        plot_model_obj,
2565                        flexation_point_detection_results,
2566                    )
2567                else:
2568                    return func.__name__, model, plot_distribution_obj, plot_model_obj
2569            elif model.model["name"] == "lognorm" and model.model["params"][0] > 2:
2570                flexation_point_detection_results = Flexation().find_distributions(
2571                    model, np.sort(data.values)
2572                )
2573                if flexation_point_detection_results != None:
2574
2575                    return (
2576                        func.__name__,
2577                        model,
2578                        plot_distribution_obj,
2579                        plot_model_obj,
2580                        flexation_point_detection_results,
2581                    )
2582                else:
2583                    return func.__name__, model, plot_distribution_obj, plot_model_obj
2584            else:
2585                return func.__name__, model, plot_distribution_obj, plot_model_obj
2586
2587        return wrapper
2588
2589
2590    @log_curve_fitting_resluts
2591    @check_curve_fit
2592    def visitation_frequency(
2593        self, data: TrajectoriesFrame, min_labels_no: int
2594    ) -> tuple:
2595        """
2596        Computes the visitation frequency of locations based
2597        on trajectory data.
2598
2599        The function:
2600        - Computes visitation frequency from trajectory data.
2601        - Averages visitation frequency over a specified
2602            minimum number of labels.
2603        - Performs curve fitting to find the best function
2604            describing the relationship.
2605        - Returns fitting results, including predictions
2606            and parameter estimates.
2607
2608        Parameters:
2609        -----------
2610        data : TrajectoriesFrame
2611            A trajectory dataset containing location visit information.
2612        min_labels_no : int
2613            Minimum number of labels required for averaging
2614                the visitation frequency.
2615
2616        Returns:
2617        --------
2618        tuple:
2619            - best_fit (str): Best fitting curve name.
2620            - global_params (pd.DataFrame): Parameters of the best fit.
2621            - y_pred (np.ndarray): Predicted visitation frequencies.
2622            - exp_y_pred (np.ndarray or None): Exponential curve
2623                predictions (if applicable).
2624            - avg_vf (pd.Series): Averaged visitation frequency data.
2625            - labels (list): Axis labels for the plot.
2626        """
2627
2628        vf = visitation_frequency(data)
2629        avg_vf = rowwise_average(vf, row_count=min_labels_no)
2630        avg_vf.index += 1
2631        vf.groupby(level=0).size().median()
2632        avg_vf = avg_vf[~avg_vf.isna()]
2633
2634        y_pred, best_fit, best_fit_params, global_params, expon_y_pred = (
2635            self.curve_fitting.model_choose(avg_vf)
2636        )
2637
2638        return best_fit, global_params, y_pred, expon_y_pred, avg_vf, ["Rank", "f"]
2639
2640
2641    @log_distribution_fitting_resluts
2642    @check_distribution_fit
2643    def jump_lengths_distribution(self, data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> tuple:
2644        """
2645        Computes the distribution of jump lengths in a trajectory dataset.
2646
2647        The function:
2648        - Extracts jump lengths from the dataset.
2649        - Removes zero values and converts the data into a distribution.
2650        - Fits multiple statistical distributions and selects the best fit.
2651
2652        Parameters:
2653        -----------
2654        data : TrajectoriesFrame
2655            A trajectory dataset containing movement data.
2656
2657        Returns:
2658        --------
2659        tuple:
2660            - model (distfit object): The fitted distribution model.
2661            - jl (pd.Series): The processed jump length data.
2662        """
2663
2664        jl = jump_lengths(data)
2665        jl = jl[jl != 0]
2666        jl_dist = convert_to_distribution(jl, num_of_classes=20)
2667
2668        # Fit to find the best theoretical distribution
2669        jl = jl[~jl.isna()]
2670        model = distfit(
2671            distr=[
2672                "norm",
2673                "expon",
2674                "pareto",
2675                "dweibull",
2676                "t",
2677                "genextreme",
2678                "gamma",
2679                "lognorm",
2680                "beta",
2681                "uniform",
2682                "loggamma",
2683                "truncexpon",
2684                "truncnorm",
2685                "truncpareto",
2686                "powerlaw",
2687            ],
2688            stats="wasserstein",
2689        )
2690        model.fit_transform(jl.values)
2691
2692        return model, jl
2693
2694
2695    @log_distribution_fitting_resluts
2696    @check_distribution_fit
2697    def waiting_times(self, data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> tuple:
2698        """
2699        Computes the distribution of waiting times in a trajectory dataset.
2700
2701        The function:
2702        - Calculates the waiting times as the difference between start
2703            and end times.
2704        - Removes missing and zero values.
2705        - Fits multiple statistical distributions and selects the best fit.
2706
2707        Parameters:
2708        -----------
2709        data : TrajectoriesFrame
2710            A trajectory dataset containing time-based movement data.
2711
2712        Returns:
2713        --------
2714        tuple:
2715            - model (distfit object): The fitted distribution model.
2716            - wt (pd.Series): The processed waiting time data.
2717        """
2718
2719        data_set = data.copy()
2720        try:
2721            wt = data_set.groupby(level=0).apply(
2722                lambda x: (x.end - x.start).dt.total_seconds().round()
2723            )
2724        except:
2725            wt = (data_set["end"] - data_set["start"]).dt.total_seconds().round()
2726
2727        wt = wt[~wt.isna()]  # type: ignore
2728        wt = wt[wt != 0]
2729
2730        # Fit to find the best theoretical distribution
2731        model = distfit(
2732            distr=[
2733                "norm",
2734                "expon",
2735                "pareto",
2736                "dweibull",
2737                "t",
2738                "genextreme",
2739                "gamma",
2740                "lognorm",
2741                "beta",
2742                "uniform",
2743                "loggamma",
2744                "truncexpon",
2745                "truncnorm",
2746                "truncpareto",
2747                "powerlaw",
2748            ],
2749            stats="wasserstein",
2750        )
2751        model.fit_transform(wt.values)
2752
2753        return model, wt
2754
2755
2756    @log_distribution_fitting_resluts
2757    @check_distribution_fit
2758    def travel_times(self, data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> tuple:
2759        """
2760        Computes the distribution of travel times between locations.
2761
2762        The function:
2763        - Calculates travel times as the time difference between
2764            consecutive trajectory points.
2765        - Removes missing values.
2766        - Fits multiple statistical distributions and selects the best fit.
2767
2768        Parameters:
2769        -----------
2770        data : TrajectoriesFrame
2771            A trajectory dataset containing time-based movement data.
2772
2773        Returns:
2774        --------
2775        tuple:
2776            - model (distfit object): The fitted distribution model.
2777            - tt (pd.Series): The processed travel time data.
2778        """
2779
2780        data_set = data.copy()
2781        try:
2782            tt = (
2783                data_set.groupby(level=0)
2784                .progress_apply(lambda x: x.shift(-1).start - x.end)  # type: ignore
2785                .reset_index(level=[1, 2], drop=True)
2786            )
2787        except:
2788            shifted_start = data_set["start"].shift(-1)
2789            tt = shifted_start - data_set["end"]
2790            tt = tt.reset_index(drop=True)
2791
2792        tt = tt.dt.total_seconds()
2793        tt = tt[~tt.isna()]
2794
2795        # Fit to find the best theoretical distribution
2796        model = distfit(
2797            distr=[
2798                "norm",
2799                "expon",
2800                "pareto",
2801                "dweibull",
2802                "t",
2803                "genextreme",
2804                "gamma",
2805                "lognorm",
2806                "beta",
2807                "uniform",
2808                "loggamma",
2809                "truncexpon",
2810                "truncnorm",
2811                "truncpareto",
2812                "powerlaw",
2813            ],
2814            stats="wasserstein",
2815        )
2816        model.fit_transform(tt.values)
2817
2818        return model, tt
2819
2820
2821    @log_distribution_fitting_resluts
2822    @check_distribution_fit
2823    def rog(self, data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> tuple:
2824        """
2825        Computes the distribution of the radius of gyration (RoG).
2826
2827        The function:
2828        - Computes the radius of gyration for each trajectory.
2829        - Fits multiple statistical distributions and selects the best fit.
2830
2831        Parameters:
2832        -----------
2833        data : TrajectoriesFrame
2834            A trajectory dataset containing spatial movement data.
2835
2836        Returns:
2837        --------
2838        tuple:
2839            - model (distfit object): The fitted distribution model.
2840            - rog (pd.Series): The processed radius of gyration data.
2841        """
2842
2843        rog = radius_of_gyration(data, time_evolution=False)
2844
2845        # Fit to find the best theoretical distribution
2846        model = distfit(
2847            distr=[
2848                "norm",
2849                "expon",
2850                "pareto",
2851                "dweibull",
2852                "t",
2853                "genextreme",
2854                "gamma",
2855                "lognorm",
2856                "beta",
2857                "uniform",
2858                "loggamma",
2859                "truncexpon",
2860                "truncnorm",
2861                "truncpareto",
2862                "powerlaw",
2863            ],
2864            stats="wasserstein",
2865        )
2866        model.fit_transform(rog.values)
2867
2868        return model, rog
2869
2870
2871    @log_curve_fitting_resluts
2872    @check_curve_fit
2873    def rog_over_time(
2874        self,
2875        data: TrajectoriesFrame,
2876        min_records_no: int
2877    ) -> tuple:
2878        """
2879        Computes the evolution of the radius of gyration (RoG) over time.
2880
2881        The function:
2882        - Computes the radius of gyration for each trajectory over time.
2883        - Averages the RoG values using a specified number of records.
2884        - Fits a curve to model the evolution of RoG.
2885
2886        Parameters:
2887        -----------
2888        data : TrajectoriesFrame
2889            A trajectory dataset containing movement data.
2890        min_records_no : int
2891            Minimum number of records required for averaging.
2892
2893        Returns:
2894        --------
2895        tuple:
2896            - best_fit (str): Name of the best fitting model.
2897            - global_params (dict): Parameters of the best fit.
2898            - y_pred (ndarray): Predicted values from the curve fit.
2899            - expon_y_pred (ndarray): Alternative exponential model
2900                predictions.
2901            - avg_rog (pd.Series): Averaged RoG values over time.
2902            - ["Time", "Values"] (list): Column labels.
2903        """
2904
2905        rog = radius_of_gyration(data, time_evolution=True)
2906        avg_rog = rowwise_average(rog, row_count=min_records_no)
2907        avg_rog = avg_rog[~avg_rog.isna()]
2908
2909        # model selection
2910        y_pred, best_fit, best_fit_params, global_params, expon_y_pred = (
2911            DistributionFitingTools().model_choose(avg_rog)
2912        )
2913
2914        return (
2915            best_fit,
2916            global_params,
2917            y_pred,
2918            expon_y_pred,
2919            avg_rog,
2920            ["Time", "Values"],
2921        )
2922
2923
2924    @log_distribution_fitting_resluts
2925    @check_distribution_fit
2926    def msd_distribution(self, data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> tuple:
2927        """
2928        Computes the distribution of mean squared displacement (MSD).
2929
2930        The function:
2931        - Computes MSD without time evolution.
2932        - Fits multiple statistical distributions and selects the best fit.
2933
2934        Parameters:
2935        -----------
2936        data : TrajectoriesFrame
2937            A trajectory dataset containing movement data.
2938
2939        Returns:
2940        --------
2941        tuple:
2942            - model (distfit object): The fitted distribution model.
2943            - msd (pd.Series): The computed MSD values.
2944        """
2945
2946        msd = mean_square_displacement(
2947            data,
2948            time_evolution=False,
2949            from_center=True
2950        )
2951        model = distfit(
2952            distr=[
2953                "norm",
2954                "expon",
2955                "pareto",
2956                "dweibull",
2957                "t",
2958                "genextreme",
2959                "gamma",
2960                "lognorm",
2961                "beta",
2962                "uniform",
2963                "loggamma",
2964                "truncexpon",
2965                "truncnorm",
2966                "truncpareto",
2967                "powerlaw",
2968            ],
2969            stats="wasserstein",
2970        )
2971        model.fit_transform(msd.values)
2972
2973        return model, msd
2974
2975
2976    @log_curve_fitting_resluts
2977    @check_curve_fit
2978    def msd_curve(
2979        self,
2980        data: TrajectoriesFrame,
2981        min_records_no: int
2982    ) -> tuple:
2983        """
2984        Computes the mean squared displacement (MSD) curve over time.
2985
2986        The function:
2987        - Computes MSD over time.
2988        - Averages MSD values using a specified number of records.
2989        - Fits a curve to model MSD behavior.
2990
2991        Parameters:
2992        -----------
2993        data : TrajectoriesFrame
2994            A trajectory dataset containing movement data.
2995        min_records_no : int
2996            Minimum number of records required for averaging.
2997
2998        Returns:
2999        --------
3000        tuple:
3001            - best_fit (str): Name of the best fitting model.
3002            - global_params (dict): Parameters of the best fit.
3003            - y_pred (ndarray): Predicted values from the curve fit.
3004            - expon_y_pred (ndarray): Alternative exponential model
3005                predictions.
3006            - avg_msd (pd.Series): Averaged MSD values over time.
3007            - ["t", "MSD"] (list): Column labels.
3008        """
3009
3010        msd = mean_square_displacement(
3011            data,
3012            time_evolution=True,
3013            from_center=False
3014        )
3015        avg_msd = rowwise_average(msd, row_count=min_records_no)
3016        avg_msd = avg_msd[~avg_msd.isna()]
3017        # model selection
3018        y_pred, best_fit, best_fit_params, global_params, expon_y_pred = (
3019            DistributionFitingTools().model_choose(avg_msd)
3020        )
3021
3022        return (
3023            best_fit,
3024            global_params,
3025            y_pred,
3026            expon_y_pred,
3027            avg_msd,
3028            ["t", "MSD"]
3029        )
3030
3031
3032    @log_distribution_fitting_resluts
3033    @check_distribution_fit
3034    def return_time_distribution(self, data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> tuple:
3035        """
3036        Computes the distribution of return times.
3037
3038        The function:
3039        - Identifies return times based on revisited locations.
3040        - Fits a statistical distribution to the return time values.
3041
3042        Parameters:
3043        -----------
3044        data : TrajectoriesFrame
3045            A trajectory dataset containing labeled locations and timestamps.
3046
3047        Returns:
3048        --------
3049        tuple:
3050            - model (distfit object): The fitted distribution model.
3051            - rt (pd.Series): The computed return time values.
3052        """
3053
3054        to_concat = {}
3055        data_set = data.copy()
3056        for uid, vals in tqdm(
3057            data_set.groupby(level=0),
3058            total=len(pd.unique(data_set.index.get_level_values(0))),
3059        ):
3060            vals = vals.sort_index()[["labels", "start", "end"]]
3061
3062            vals["new_place"] = ~vals["labels"].duplicated(keep="first")
3063            vals["islands"] = vals["new_place"] * (
3064                (vals["new_place"] != vals["new_place"].shift(1)).cumsum()
3065            )
3066            vals["islands_reach"] = vals["islands"].shift()
3067            vals["islands"] = vals[["islands", "islands_reach"]].max(axis=1)
3068
3069            vals = vals.drop("islands_reach", axis=1)
3070            vals = vals[vals.islands > 0]
3071
3072            result = vals.groupby("islands").apply(
3073                lambda x: x.iloc[-1].start - x.iloc[0].start if len(x) > 0 else None  # type: ignore
3074            )
3075            result = result.dt.total_seconds()
3076            to_concat[uid] = result
3077
3078        rt = pd.concat(to_concat)
3079        rt = rt.reset_index(level=1, drop=True)
3080        rt = rt[rt != 0]
3081        rt = pd.concat(to_concat)
3082        rt = rt[rt != 0]
3083
3084        model = distfit(stats="wasserstein")
3085        model.fit_transform(rt.values)
3086
3087        return model, rt
3088
3089
3090    @log_distribution_fitting_resluts
3091    @check_distribution_fit
3092    def exploration_time(self, data: TrajectoriesFrame) -> tuple:
3093        """
3094        Computes the distribution of exploration times.
3095
3096        The function:
3097        - Identifies exploration periods as the time spent in
3098            newly visited locations.
3099        - Fits a statistical distribution to the exploration time values.
3100
3101        Parameters:
3102        -----------
3103        data : TrajectoriesFrame
3104            A trajectory dataset containing labeled locations and timestamps.
3105
3106        Returns:
3107        --------
3108        tuple:
3109            - model (distfit object): The fitted distribution model.
3110            - et (pd.Series): The computed exploration time values.
3111        """
3112
3113        to_concat = {}
3114        data_set = data.copy()
3115        for uid, vals in tqdm(
3116            data_set.groupby(level=0),
3117            total=len(pd.unique(data_set.index.get_level_values(0))),
3118        ):
3119            vals = vals.sort_index()[["labels", "start", "end"]]
3120
3121            vals["old_place"] = vals["labels"].duplicated(keep="first")
3122            vals["islands"] = vals["old_place"] * (
3123                (vals["old_place"] != vals["old_place"].shift(1)).cumsum()
3124            )
3125            vals["islands_reach"] = vals["islands"].shift()
3126            vals["islands"] = vals[["islands", "islands_reach"]].max(axis=1)
3127
3128            vals = vals.drop("islands_reach", axis=1)
3129            vals = vals[vals.islands > 0]
3130
3131            result = vals.groupby("islands").apply(
3132                lambda x: x.iloc[-1].start - x.iloc[0].start if len(x) > 0 else None  # type: ignore
3133            )
3134            if result.size == 0:
3135                continue
3136            result = result.dt.total_seconds()
3137            to_concat[uid] = result
3138
3139        et = pd.concat(to_concat)
3140        et = et.reset_index(level=1, drop=True)
3141        et = et[et != 0]
3142
3143        model = distfit(stats="wasserstein")
3144        model.fit_transform(et.values)
3145
3146        return model, et
3147
3148
3149    @log_msd_split
3150    def msd_curve_split(self, data):
3151        """
3152        Computes and groups MSD curves based on the radius of gyration (RoG).
3153
3154        The function:
3155        - Converts trajectory data to a GeoDataFrame.
3156        - Computes the center of mass and starting points for each trajectory.
3157        - Filters data to only include new explorations.
3158        - Computes MSD and RoG values for each group.
3159        - Groups MSD curves based on RoG bins and fits curves to them.
3160
3161        Parameters:
3162        -----------
3163        data : pd.DataFrame
3164            A dataset containing longitude and latitude coordinates.
3165
3166        Returns:
3167        --------
3168        tuple:
3169            - msd_results (pd.DataFrame): Summary of MSD curve fitting for
3170                different RoG ranges.
3171            - buffer (BytesIO): A buffer containing the saved MSD plot.
3172        """
3173
3174        gdf = gpd.GeoDataFrame(
3175            data, geometry=gpd.points_from_xy(data["lon"], data["lat"])
3176        )
3177        gdf.crs = 4326
3178        gdf = gdf.to_crs(3857)
3179        com = gdf.groupby(level=0).apply(
3180            lambda z: Point(z.geometry.x.mean(), z.geometry.y.mean())
3181        )
3182        starting_points = (
3183            gdf.groupby(level=0).head(1).droplevel(1).geometry
3184        )
3185        to_concat_msd = []
3186        to_concat_rog = {}
3187        for ind, vals in gdf.groupby(level=0):
3188            vals["is_new"] = ~vals.labels.duplicated(keep="first")
3189            vals = vals[vals["is_new"]]
3190            vals = vals.dropna()[1:]
3191            msd_ind = vals.distance(starting_points.loc[ind]) ** 2
3192            rog_ind = vals.distance(com.loc[ind]) ** 2
3193            msd_ind = groupwise_expansion(msd_ind)
3194            to_concat_msd.append(msd_ind)
3195            to_concat_rog[ind] = np.sqrt(rog_ind).mean()
3196        final_msd = pd.concat(to_concat_msd)
3197        final_rog = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(
3198            to_concat_rog, orient="index"
3199        )
3200
3201        final_rog["bins"] = pd.cut(
3202            final_rog.values.ravel(),
3203            bins=[
3204                0, 2e3, 4e3, 8e3, 16e3, 32e3, 64e3, 128e3, 256e3, 512e3, 1024e3
3205            ],
3206        )
3207        msd_results = pd.DataFrame(
3208            columns=["RoG range [km]", "curve", "param1", "param2"]
3209        )
3210        buffer = BytesIO()
3211        sns.set_style("whitegrid")
3212        plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4.5))
3213        for ind, vals in final_rog.groupby("bins"):
3214            if vals.empty:
3215                continue
3216            if vals.shape[0] < 2:
3217                continue
3218            msd_pick = final_msd.loc[vals.index.values]
3219            msd_rows = int(
3220                msd_pick.groupby(level=0).apply(lambda x: len(x)).min()
3221            )  # find min number of rows for
3222            # individuals
3223            msd_pick_avg = rowwise_average(msd_pick, msd_rows)
3224            try:  # now average rowwise
3225                msd_chosen = DistributionFitingTools().model_choose(
3226                    msd_pick_avg
3227                )  # pick model
3228            except ValueError:
3229                continue
3230            if len(msd_chosen[0]) < 3:
3231                continue
3232            avg_error = r2_score(
3233                np.log(msd_pick_avg[1:]), np.log(msd_chosen[0][1:])
3234            )
3235            if avg_error < 0.25:
3236                continue
3237            msd_results = msd_results._append(
3238                {
3239                    "RoG range [km]": f"{(int(ind.left/1000))}-{(int(ind.right/1000))}",
3240                    "curve": msd_chosen[1],
3241                    "param1": msd_chosen[2][0],
3242                    "param2": msd_chosen[2][1],  # type: ignore
3243                },
3244                ignore_index=True,
3245            )
3246            plt.scatter(np.arange(msd_rows), msd_pick_avg.values)
3247            plt.plot(
3248                np.arange(msd_pick_avg.shape[0]),
3249                msd_chosen[0],
3250                label=f"RoG:<{(int(ind.right/1000))}km ({vals.shape[0]})"
3251            )  # type: ignore
3252
3253        plt.legend()
3254        plt.loglog()
3255        plt.xlabel("t")
3256        plt.ylabel("MSD")
3257        plt.savefig(
3258            os.path.join(
3259                self.output_path,
3260                "MSD split.png",
3261            )
3262        )
3263        plt.savefig(buffer, format="png")
3264        plt.close()
3265        buffer.seek(0)
3266
3267        return msd_results, buffer
3268
3269
3270    @log_curve_fitting_resluts
3271    @check_curve_fit
3272    def distinct_locations_over_time(
3273        self,
3274        nrows:int,
3275        n_data:int,
3276        data:pd.Series
3277    ) -> tuple:
3278        """
3279        Computes the number of distinct locations visited over time.
3280
3281        The function:
3282        - Computes the cumulative number of distinct locations visited.
3283        - Fits a curve to model the growth of visited locations over time.
3284
3285        Parameters:
3286        -----------
3287        nrows : int
3288            Number of rows in the dataset.
3289        n_data : int
3290            Total data points available.
3291        data : pd.Series
3292            A dataset containing the count of distinct locations.
3293
3294        Returns:
3295        --------
3296        tuple:
3297            - best_fit (str): Name of the best fitting model.
3298            - global_params (dict): Parameters of the best fit.
3299            - y_pred (ndarray): Predicted values from the curve fit.
3300            - expon_y_pred (ndarray): Alternative exponential model
3301                predictions.
3302            - pd.Series(data): The input data as a pandas Series.
3303            - ["t", "S(t)"] (list): Column labels.
3304        """
3305
3306        y_pred, best_fit, best_fit_params, global_params, expon_y_pred = (
3307            DistributionFitingTools().model_choose(pd.Series(data))
3308        )
3309
3310        return (
3311            best_fit,
3312            global_params,
3313            y_pred,
3314            expon_y_pred,
3315            pd.Series(data),
3316            ["t", "S(t)"],
3317        )
3318
3319
3320    @log_pnew_estimation
3321    def estimate_pnew(self, filled_data:pd.DataFrame) -> tuple:
3322        """
3323        Estimates parameters (rho, gamma) for the probability of
3324        discovering new locations.
3325
3326        The function:
3327        - Computes the rate of discovery of new locations (P_new).
3328        - Fits a linear model in log-log space to estimate the parameters.
3329
3330        Parameters:
3331        -----------
3332        nrows : int
3333            Number of rows in the dataset.
3334        n_data : int
3335            Total data points available.
3336        S_t : list or np.array
3337            Sequence of distinct locations visited over time.
3338
3339        Returns:
3340        --------
3341        tuple:
3342            - rho_hat (float): Estimated rho parameter.
3343            - gamma_hat (float): Estimated gamma parameter.
3344            - DeltaS (np.array): Changes in S(t).
3345            - S_mid (np.array): Midpoints of S(t).
3346            - intercept (float): Intercept of the log-log regression.
3347            - slope (float): Slope of the log-log regression (negative gamma).
3348            - nrows (int): Number of rows in the dataset.
3349            - n_data (int): Total data points available.
3350        """
3351        filled_data.to_csv("filled_data.csv")
3352        nrows = int(filled_data.groupby(level=0).apply(lambda x: len(x)).min())
3353        t_array = np.arange(1, nrows + 1)
3354
3355        n_array = filled_data.next.groupby(level=0).apply(lambda x: x.cumsum())
3356        n_array = np.array([n_array.groupby(level=0).nth(x).mean() for x in range(nrows)])
3357
3358
3359        S_array = np.array([filled_data.groupby(level=0)['new_sum'].nth(x).mean() for x in range(nrows)])
3360
3361        fit_n = powerlaw.Fit(n_array + 1e-10, discrete=True, verbose=False)
3362        beta_est = fit_n.power_law.alpha - 1
3363        C_est = np.exp(np.mean(np.log(n_array + 1e-10) - beta_est * np.log(t_array)))
3364
3365        fit_s = powerlaw.Fit(S_array + 1e-10, discrete=True, verbose=False)
3366        alpha_est = fit_s.power_law.alpha - 1
3367        K_est = np.exp(np.mean(np.log(S_array + 1e-10) - alpha_est * np.log(t_array)))
3368
3369        # Gamma from theory
3370        gamma_est = beta_est / alpha_est - 1
3371
3372        # Estimate rho from prefactor relation
3373        num = np.log(K_est) - np.log(1 + gamma_est)
3374        den = 1.0 / (1.0 + gamma_est)
3375        temp = num / den - np.log(C_est)
3376        rho_est = np.exp(temp)
3377
3378        gamma = gamma_est
3379        rho = rho_est
3380
3381
3382        DeltaS = S_array[1:] - S_array[:-1]
3383        S_mid = S_array[:-1]
3384        slope = -gamma
3385        intercept = temp
3386
3387        mask = (DeltaS > 0) & (S_mid > 0)
3388        DeltaS = DeltaS[mask]
3389        S_mid = S_mid[mask]
3390
3391        # S_t = np.array(S_t)
3392        # DeltaS = S_t[1:] - S_t[:-1]
3393        # S_mid = S_t[:-1]
3394        # mask = (DeltaS > 0) & (S_mid > 0)
3395        # DeltaS = DeltaS[mask]
3396        # S_mid = S_mid[mask]
3397
3398        # X = np.log(S_mid).reshape(-1, 1)  # predictor
3399        # y = np.log(DeltaS)  # response
3400
3401        # model = LinearRegression()
3402        # model.fit(X, y)
3403
3404        # slope = model.coef_[0]
3405        # intercept = model.intercept_
3406        # gamma_est = -slope
3407        # rho_est = np.exp(intercept)
3408
3409        return (
3410            rho,
3411            gamma,
3412            DeltaS,
3413            S_mid,
3414            intercept,
3415            slope,
3416            nrows,
3417            t_array
3418            )

A class for handling statistical data analysis and generating reports in PDF format.

This class takes in a dataset, performs statistical analysis, applies curve fitting techniques, and generates a PDF report summarizing the results.

Parameters:

pdf_object : FPDF An instance of the FPDF class used for generating the PDF report. stats_frame : DataSetStats An instance of DataSetStats containing statistical information about the dataset. output_path : str The file path where the generated PDF report will be saved.

Attributes:

pdf_object : FPDF The PDF object used for report generation. output_path : str The location where the final report will be stored. stats_frame : DataSetStats The dataset statistics object containing calculated metrics. curve_fitting : DistributionFitingTools A toolset for fitting distributions to the dataset.

Laws( pdf_object: fpdf.fpdf.FPDF, stats_frame: DataSetStats, output_path: str) 
1601    def __init__(
1602            self,
1603            pdf_object: FPDF,
1604            stats_frame: DataSetStats,
1605            output_path: str
1606        ):
1607        """
1608        Parameters:
1609        -----------
1610        pdf_object : FPDF
1611            An instance of the `FPDF` class used for generating the
1612                PDF report.
1613        stats_frame : DataSetStats
1614            An instance of `DataSetStats` containing statistical
1615                information about the dataset.
1616        output_path : str
1617            The file path where the generated PDF report will be saved.
1618        """
1619
1620        self.pdf_object = pdf_object
1621        self.output_path = output_path
1622        self.stats_frame = stats_frame
1623        self.curve_fitting = DistributionFitingTools()

Parameters:

pdf_object : FPDF An instance of the FPDF class used for generating the PDF report. stats_frame : DataSetStats An instance of DataSetStats containing statistical information about the dataset. output_path : str The file path where the generated PDF report will be saved.

def log_curve_fitting_resluts(func): 
2157    def log_curve_fitting_resluts(func):
2158        """
2159        A decorator that logs and saves curve fitting results
2160        to a PDF report.
2161
2162        The decorated function is expected to return:
2163        - func_name (str): Name of the function.
2164        - best_fit (str): Name of the best-fitting curve.
2165        - param_frame (pd.DataFrame): DataFrame containing
2166            curve parameters.
2167        - plot_obj (BytesIO): The plot image object.
2168
2169        The results are logged in `self.stats_frame`
2170            and added to a PDF report.
2171
2172        Parameters:
2173        -----------
2174        func : function
2175            The function performing curve fitting.
2176
2177        Returns:
2178        --------
2179        function
2180            Wrapped function with additional logging and PDF output.
2181        """
2182
2183        def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
2184            func_name, best_fit, param_frame, plot_obj = func(self, *args, **kwargs)
2185            filtered_df = param_frame[param_frame["curve"] == best_fit]
2186
2187            self.stats_frame.add_data({func_name: best_fit})
2188            self.stats_frame.add_data(
2189                {
2190                    f"{func_name}_params": filtered_df[
2191                        ["param1", "param2"]
2192                    ].values.tolist()
2193                }
2194            )
2195
2196            func_name = func_name.replace("_", " ").split(" ")
2197            func_name[0] = func_name[0].capitalize()
2198            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", "B", size=8)
2199            self._add_pdf_cell(f"{' '.join(func_name)}")
2200            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", size=7)
2201            self._add_pdf_cell(
2202                f'Best fit: {best_fit} with Param 1: {filtered_df["param1"].values[0]},'
2203                f'Param 2: {filtered_df["param2"].values[0]}'
2204            )
2205
2206            y_position_global = float(self.pdf_object.get_y())
2207            self._add_pdf_curves_table(
2208                param_frame, x_offset=10, y_offset=y_position_global + 13
2209            )
2210            self._add_pdf_plot(
2211                plot_obj=plot_obj,
2212                image_width=80,
2213                image_height=45,
2214                x_position=125,
2215                y_position=y_position_global,
2216            )
2217
2218        return wrapper

A decorator that logs and saves curve fitting results to a PDF report.

The decorated function is expected to return:

  • func_name (str): Name of the function.
  • best_fit (str): Name of the best-fitting curve.
  • param_frame (pd.DataFrame): DataFrame containing curve parameters.
  • plot_obj (BytesIO): The plot image object.

The results are logged in self.stats_frame and added to a PDF report.

Parameters:

func : function The function performing curve fitting.

Returns:

function Wrapped function with additional logging and PDF output.

def log_distribution_fitting_resluts(func): 
2221    def log_distribution_fitting_resluts(func):
2222        """
2223        A decorator that logs and saves distribution fitting
2224        results to a PDF report.
2225
2226        The decorated function is expected to return:
2227        - results[0] (str): The name of the fitted distribution.
2228        - results[1] (distfit object): Fitted distribution model.
2229        - results[2] (BytesIO): Distribution plot.
2230        - results[3] (BytesIO): Model plot.
2231        - results[4] (tuple, optional): If present, contains
2232            information about a flexion point.
2233
2234        If a flexion point is detected, it logs both left
2235        and right distributions and plots them separately.
2236
2237        Parameters:
2238        -----------
2239        func : function
2240            The function performing distribution fitting.
2241
2242        Returns:
2243        --------
2244        function
2245            Wrapped function with additional logging and PDF output.
2246        """
2247
2248        def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
2249            results = func(self, *args, **kwargs)
2250
2251            self.stats_frame.add_data({results[0]: results[1].model["name"]})
2252            self.stats_frame.add_data(
2253                {f"{results[0]}_params": results[1].model["params"]}
2254            )
2255
2256            func_name = results[0].replace("_", " ").split(" ")
2257            func_name[0] = func_name[0].capitalize()
2258            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", "B", size=8)
2259            self._add_pdf_cell(f"{' '.join(func_name)}")
2260            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", size=7)
2261            self._add_pdf_cell(
2262                f'Best fit: {results[1].model["name"]} with params: {results[1].model["params"]}'
2263            )
2264
2265            self._add_pdf_distribution_table(
2266                results[1].summary[["name", "score", "params"]]
2267            )
2268            y_position_global = float(self.pdf_object.get_y())
2269            self._add_pdf_plot(
2270                results[2], 80, 60, x_position=10, y_position=y_position_global
2271            )
2272            self._add_pdf_plot(
2273                results[3], 80, 60, x_position=110, y_position=y_position_global
2274            )
2275
2276            if len(results) == 5:
2277                self._add_pdf_cell(
2278                    f"At point {results[4][4]}, the flexion point of the distributions was found"
2279                )
2280                self._add_pdf_cell(
2281                    f'Left distribution is {results[4][0].model["name"]} with params: {results[4][0].model["params"]}'
2282                )
2283                self._add_pdf_cell(
2284                    f'Right distribution is {results[4][1].model["name"]} with params: {results[4][1].model["params"]}'
2285                )
2286                self._add_pdf_distribution_table(
2287                    results[4][1].summary[["name", "score", "params"]]
2288                )
2289                plot_distribution, plot_models = self._plot_double_distribution(
2290                    results[4][0],
2291                    results[4][1],
2292                    results[4][2],
2293                    results[4][3],
2294                    results[4][4],
2295                    results[0],
2296                )
2297                y_position_global = float(self.pdf_object.get_y())
2298                self._add_pdf_plot(
2299                    plot_distribution,
2300                    80,
2301                    60,
2302                    x_position=10,
2303                    y_position=y_position_global,
2304                )
2305                self._add_pdf_plot(
2306                    plot_models, 80, 60, x_position=110, y_position=y_position_global
2307                )
2308            self.pdf_object.add_page()
2309
2310        return wrapper

A decorator that logs and saves distribution fitting results to a PDF report.

The decorated function is expected to return:

  • results[0] (str): The name of the fitted distribution.
  • results[1] (distfit object): Fitted distribution model.
  • results[2] (BytesIO): Distribution plot.
  • results[3] (BytesIO): Model plot.
  • results[4] (tuple, optional): If present, contains information about a flexion point.

If a flexion point is detected, it logs both left and right distributions and plots them separately.

Parameters:

func : function The function performing distribution fitting.

Returns:

function Wrapped function with additional logging and PDF output.

def log_pnew_estimation(func): 
2313    def log_pnew_estimation(func):
2314        """
2315        A decorator that logs and saves P_new estimation results
2316        to a PDF report.
2317
2318        The decorated function is expected to return:
2319        - rho_est (float): Estimated rho parameter.
2320        - gamma_est (float): Estimated gamma parameter.
2321        - DeltaS (np.ndarray): Change in S values for log-log regression.
2322        - S_mid (np.ndarray): Midpoints of S values for log-log regression.
2323        - intercept (float): Intercept of the fitted regression line.
2324        - slope (float): Slope of the fitted regression line.
2325        - nrows (int): Number of time steps for estimation.
2326        - n_data (int): Number of data points.
2327
2328        The results are logged in `self.stats_frame`
2329        and visualized in a PDF.
2330
2331        Parameters:
2332        -----------
2333        func : function
2334            The function performing P_new estimation.
2335
2336        Returns:
2337        --------
2338        function
2339            Wrapped function with additional logging and PDF output.
2340        """
2341
2342        def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
2343            rho_est, gamma_est, DeltaS, S_mid, intercept, slope, nrows, n_data = func(
2344                self, *args, **kwargs
2345            )  # type: ignore
2346
2347            self.stats_frame.add_data({"rho": rho_est})
2348            self.stats_frame.add_data({"gamma": gamma_est})
2349
2350            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", "B", size=8)
2351            self._add_pdf_cell("Pnew estimation")
2352
2353            self.pdf_object.ln()
2354            self.pdf_object.ln()
2355            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", size=7)
2356            self._add_pdf_cell(f"gamma  = {gamma_est:.4f}")
2357            self._add_pdf_cell(f"rho  = {rho_est:.4f}")
2358            y_position_global = float(self.pdf_object.get_y())
2359            plot_obj1, plot_obj2 = self._plot_P_new(
2360                rho_est, gamma_est, DeltaS, S_mid, intercept, slope, nrows, n_data
2361            )
2362            self._add_pdf_plot(
2363                plot_obj=plot_obj1,
2364                image_width=80,
2365                image_height=45,
2366                x_position=10,
2367                y_position=y_position_global,
2368            )
2369            self._add_pdf_plot(
2370                plot_obj=plot_obj2,
2371                image_width=80,
2372                image_height=45,
2373                x_position=110,
2374                y_position=y_position_global,
2375            )
2376
2377        return wrapper

A decorator that logs and saves P_new estimation results to a PDF report.

The decorated function is expected to return:

  • rho_est (float): Estimated rho parameter.
  • gamma_est (float): Estimated gamma parameter.
  • DeltaS (np.ndarray): Change in S values for log-log regression.
  • S_mid (np.ndarray): Midpoints of S values for log-log regression.
  • intercept (float): Intercept of the fitted regression line.
  • slope (float): Slope of the fitted regression line.
  • nrows (int): Number of time steps for estimation.
  • n_data (int): Number of data points.

The results are logged in self.stats_frame and visualized in a PDF.

Parameters:

func : function The function performing P_new estimation.

Returns:

function Wrapped function with additional logging and PDF output.

def log_msd_split(func): 
2380    def log_msd_split(func):
2381        """
2382        A decorator that logs and saves MSD split results
2383        to a PDF report.
2384
2385        The decorated function is expected to return:
2386        - msd_results (pd.DataFrame): MSD split results
2387            including range and curve parameters.
2388        - plot_obj (BytesIO): The plot image object.
2389
2390        The results are stored in `self.stats_frame`
2391        and included in a PDF report.
2392
2393        Parameters:
2394        -----------
2395        func : function
2396            The function performing MSD split analysis.
2397
2398        Returns:
2399        --------
2400        function
2401            Wrapped function with additional logging and PDF output.
2402        """
2403
2404        def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
2405            msd_results, plot_obj = func(self, *args, **kwargs)  # type: ignore
2406            msd_curve = "; ".join(
2407                msd_results["RoG range [km]"] + ": " + msd_results["curve"]
2408            )
2409            msd_curve_params = "; ".join(
2410                msd_results["RoG range [km]"]
2411                + "("
2412                + msd_results["curve"]
2413                + ")"
2414                + ":"
2415                + msd_results["param1"].astype(str)
2416                + ","
2417                + msd_results["param2"].astype(str)
2418            )
2419
2420            self.stats_frame.add_data({"msd_curve": msd_curve})
2421            self.stats_frame.add_data({"msd_curve_params": msd_curve_params})
2422
2423            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", "B", size=8)
2424            self._add_pdf_cell("MSD split")
2425            y_position_global = float(self.pdf_object.get_y())
2426            self.pdf_object.ln(4)
2427            self._add_pdf_msd_split_table(msd_results)
2428            self._add_pdf_plot(
2429                plot_obj=plot_obj,
2430                image_width=80,
2431                image_height=45,
2432                x_position=125,
2433                y_position=y_position_global,
2434            )
2435
2436        return wrapper

A decorator that logs and saves MSD split results to a PDF report.

The decorated function is expected to return:

  • msd_results (pd.DataFrame): MSD split results including range and curve parameters.
  • plot_obj (BytesIO): The plot image object.

The results are stored in self.stats_frame and included in a PDF report.

Parameters:

func : function The function performing MSD split analysis.

Returns:

function Wrapped function with additional logging and PDF output.

def check_curve_fit(func): 
2439    def check_curve_fit(func):
2440        """
2441        A decorator that evaluates curve fitting results
2442        and generates a corresponding plot.
2443
2444        The decorated function is expected to return:
2445        - best_fit (str): Name of the best-fitting curve.
2446        - param_frame (pd.DataFrame): DataFrame containing
2447            curve parameters.
2448        - y_pred (np.ndarray): Predicted values based on
2449            the curve fitting.
2450        - exp_y_pred (np.ndarray or None): Exponential
2451            curve prediction (if applicable).
2452        - plot_data (pd.Series or np.ndarray): Data used for fitting.
2453        - labels (list): Axis labels for the plot.
2454
2455        If `best_fit` is not among {"linear", "expon", "expon_neg"},
2456        both the fitted curve and an additional exponential curve
2457        are plotted. Otherwise, only the fitted curve is plotted.
2458
2459        Parameters:
2460        -----------
2461        func : function
2462            The function performing curve fitting.
2463
2464        Returns:
2465        --------
2466        function
2467            Wrapped function that returns:
2468            - func.__name__ (str): Name of the function.
2469            - best_fit (str): Best fitting curve name.
2470            - param_frame (pd.DataFrame): Parameters of
2471                the best fit.
2472            - plot_obj (BytesIO): Image object containing
2473                the generated plot.
2474        """
2475
2476        def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
2477            best_fit, param_frame, y_pred, exp_y_pred, plot_data, labels = func(
2478                self, *args, **kwargs
2479            )  # type: ignore
2480            if best_fit not in {"linear", "expon", "expon_neg"}:
2481                plot_obj = self._plot_curve(
2482                    func.__name__, plot_data, y_pred, labels, exp_y_pred
2483                )
2484                return func.__name__, best_fit, param_frame, plot_obj
2485            else:
2486                plot_obj = self._plot_curve(func.__name__, plot_data, y_pred, labels)
2487                return func.__name__, best_fit, param_frame, plot_obj
2488
2489        return wrapper

A decorator that evaluates curve fitting results and generates a corresponding plot.

The decorated function is expected to return:

  • best_fit (str): Name of the best-fitting curve.
  • param_frame (pd.DataFrame): DataFrame containing curve parameters.
  • y_pred (np.ndarray): Predicted values based on the curve fitting.
  • exp_y_pred (np.ndarray or None): Exponential curve prediction (if applicable).
  • plot_data (pd.Series or np.ndarray): Data used for fitting.
  • labels (list): Axis labels for the plot.

If best_fit is not among {"linear", "expon", "expon_neg"}, both the fitted curve and an additional exponential curve are plotted. Otherwise, only the fitted curve is plotted.

Parameters:

func : function The function performing curve fitting.

Returns:

function Wrapped function that returns: - func.__name__ (str): Name of the function. - best_fit (str): Best fitting curve name. - param_frame (pd.DataFrame): Parameters of the best fit. - plot_obj (BytesIO): Image object containing the generated plot.

def check_distribution_fit(func): 
2492    def check_distribution_fit(func):
2493        """
2494        A decorator that evaluates the results of distribution
2495        fitting and detects flexation points.
2496
2497        The decorated function is expected to return:
2498        - model (distfit object): The best-fitted distribution
2499            model.
2500        - data (pd.Series or np.ndarray): Data used for
2501            distribution fitting.
2502
2503        The function generates:
2504        - A histogram plot of the fitted distribution.
2505        - A model plot displaying the probability density function (PDF).
2506
2507        If the fitted distribution is not in `const.DISTRIBUTIONS`
2508        and the data has at least 4 observations, or if specific conditions
2509        apply (e.g., Pareto or Lognormal with parameter > 2),
2510        an attempt is made to detect flexation points in the distribution.
2511
2512        Parameters:
2513        -----------
2514        func : function
2515            The function performing distribution fitting.
2516
2517        Returns:
2518        --------
2519        function
2520            Wrapped function that returns:
2521            - func.__name__ (str): Name of the function.
2522            - model (distfit object): Best-fitting distribution model.
2523            - plot_distribution_obj (BytesIO): Image object containing
2524                the histogram plot.
2525            - plot_model_obj (BytesIO): Image object containing the PDF plot.
2526            - flexation_point_detection_results (tuple, optional):
2527            If flexation points are found, returns details of left
2528            and right distributions.
2529        """
2530
2531        def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
2532            model, data = func(self, *args, **kwargs)
2533
2534            plot_distribution_obj, plot_model_obj = self._plot_distribution(
2535                model, data, func.__name__
2536            )
2537            if (
2538                model.model["name"] not in const.DISTRIBUTIONS and data.shape[0] >= 4
2539            ):  # FIXME:
2540                flexation_point_detection_results = Flexation().find_distributions(
2541                    model, np.sort(data.values)
2542                )
2543                if flexation_point_detection_results != None:
2544
2545                    return (
2546                        func.__name__,
2547                        model,
2548                        plot_distribution_obj,
2549                        plot_model_obj,
2550                        flexation_point_detection_results,
2551                    )
2552                else:
2553                    return func.__name__, model, plot_distribution_obj, plot_model_obj
2554            elif model.model["name"] == "pareto" and model.model["params"][0] > 2:
2555                flexation_point_detection_results = Flexation().find_distributions(
2556                    model, np.sort(data.values)
2557                )
2558                if flexation_point_detection_results != None:
2559
2560                    return (
2561                        func.__name__,
2562                        model,
2563                        plot_distribution_obj,
2564                        plot_model_obj,
2565                        flexation_point_detection_results,
2566                    )
2567                else:
2568                    return func.__name__, model, plot_distribution_obj, plot_model_obj
2569            elif model.model["name"] == "lognorm" and model.model["params"][0] > 2:
2570                flexation_point_detection_results = Flexation().find_distributions(
2571                    model, np.sort(data.values)
2572                )
2573                if flexation_point_detection_results != None:
2574
2575                    return (
2576                        func.__name__,
2577                        model,
2578                        plot_distribution_obj,
2579                        plot_model_obj,
2580                        flexation_point_detection_results,
2581                    )
2582                else:
2583                    return func.__name__, model, plot_distribution_obj, plot_model_obj
2584            else:
2585                return func.__name__, model, plot_distribution_obj, plot_model_obj
2586
2587        return wrapper

A decorator that evaluates the results of distribution fitting and detects flexation points.

The decorated function is expected to return:

  • model (distfit object): The best-fitted distribution model.
  • data (pd.Series or np.ndarray): Data used for distribution fitting.

The function generates:

  • A histogram plot of the fitted distribution.
  • A model plot displaying the probability density function (PDF).

If the fitted distribution is not in const.DISTRIBUTIONS and the data has at least 4 observations, or if specific conditions apply (e.g., Pareto or Lognormal with parameter > 2), an attempt is made to detect flexation points in the distribution.

Parameters:

func : function The function performing distribution fitting.

Returns:

function Wrapped function that returns: - func.__name__ (str): Name of the function. - model (distfit object): Best-fitting distribution model. - plot_distribution_obj (BytesIO): Image object containing the histogram plot. - plot_model_obj (BytesIO): Image object containing the PDF plot. - flexation_point_detection_results (tuple, optional): If flexation points are found, returns details of left and right distributions.

def visitation_frequency(self, *args, **kwargs): 
2183        def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
2184            func_name, best_fit, param_frame, plot_obj = func(self, *args, **kwargs)
2185            filtered_df = param_frame[param_frame["curve"] == best_fit]
2186
2187            self.stats_frame.add_data({func_name: best_fit})
2188            self.stats_frame.add_data(
2189                {
2190                    f"{func_name}_params": filtered_df[
2191                        ["param1", "param2"]
2192                    ].values.tolist()
2193                }
2194            )
2195
2196            func_name = func_name.replace("_", " ").split(" ")
2197            func_name[0] = func_name[0].capitalize()
2198            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", "B", size=8)
2199            self._add_pdf_cell(f"{' '.join(func_name)}")
2200            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", size=7)
2201            self._add_pdf_cell(
2202                f'Best fit: {best_fit} with Param 1: {filtered_df["param1"].values[0]},'
2203                f'Param 2: {filtered_df["param2"].values[0]}'
2204            )
2205
2206            y_position_global = float(self.pdf_object.get_y())
2207            self._add_pdf_curves_table(
2208                param_frame, x_offset=10, y_offset=y_position_global + 13
2209            )
2210            self._add_pdf_plot(
2211                plot_obj=plot_obj,
2212                image_width=80,
2213                image_height=45,
2214                x_position=125,
2215                y_position=y_position_global,
2216            )

Computes the visitation frequency of locations based on trajectory data.

The function:

  • Computes visitation frequency from trajectory data.
  • Averages visitation frequency over a specified minimum number of labels.
  • Performs curve fitting to find the best function describing the relationship.
  • Returns fitting results, including predictions and parameter estimates.

Parameters:

data : TrajectoriesFrame A trajectory dataset containing location visit information. min_labels_no : int Minimum number of labels required for averaging the visitation frequency.

Returns:

tuple: - best_fit (str): Best fitting curve name. - global_params (pd.DataFrame): Parameters of the best fit. - y_pred (np.ndarray): Predicted visitation frequencies. - exp_y_pred (np.ndarray or None): Exponential curve predictions (if applicable). - avg_vf (pd.Series): Averaged visitation frequency data. - labels (list): Axis labels for the plot.

2274            )

2294                    results[4][4],
2295                    results[0],
2296                )

2298                self._add_pdf_plot(
2299                    plot_distribution,
2300                    80,
2301                    60,
2302                    x_position=10,
2303                    y_position=y_position_global,
2304                )
2305                self._add_pdf_plot(
2306                    plot_models, 80, 60, x_position=110, y_position=y_position_global
2307                )
2308            self.pdf_object.add_page()

Computes the distribution of jump lengths in a trajectory dataset.

The function:

  • Extracts jump lengths from the dataset.
  • Removes zero values and converts the data into a distribution.
  • Fits multiple statistical distributions and selects the best fit.

Parameters:

data : TrajectoriesFrame A trajectory dataset containing movement data.

Returns:

tuple: - model (distfit object): The fitted distribution model. - jl (pd.Series): The processed jump length data.

def waiting_times(self, *args, **kwargs): 
2248        def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
2249            results = func(self, *args, **kwargs)
2250
2251            self.stats_frame.add_data({results[0]: results[1].model["name"]})
2252            self.stats_frame.add_data(
2253                {f"{results[0]}_params": results[1].model["params"]}
2254            )
2255
2256            func_name = results[0].replace("_", " ").split(" ")
2257            func_name[0] = func_name[0].capitalize()
2258            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", "B", size=8)
2259            self._add_pdf_cell(f"{' '.join(func_name)}")
2260            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", size=7)
2261            self._add_pdf_cell(
2262                f'Best fit: {results[1].model["name"]} with params: {results[1].model["params"]}'
2263            )
2264
2265            self._add_pdf_distribution_table(
2266                results[1].summary[["name", "score", "params"]]
2267            )
2268            y_position_global = float(self.pdf_object.get_y())
2269            self._add_pdf_plot(
2270                results[2], 80, 60, x_position=10, y_position=y_position_global
2271            )
2272            self._add_pdf_plot(
2273                results[3], 80, 60, x_position=110, y_position=y_position_global
2274            )
2275
2276            if len(results) == 5:
2277                self._add_pdf_cell(
2278                    f"At point {results[4][4]}, the flexion point of the distributions was found"
2279                )
2280                self._add_pdf_cell(
2281                    f'Left distribution is {results[4][0].model["name"]} with params: {results[4][0].model["params"]}'
2282                )
2283                self._add_pdf_cell(
2284                    f'Right distribution is {results[4][1].model["name"]} with params: {results[4][1].model["params"]}'
2285                )
2286                self._add_pdf_distribution_table(
2287                    results[4][1].summary[["name", "score", "params"]]
2288                )
2289                plot_distribution, plot_models = self._plot_double_distribution(
2290                    results[4][0],
2291                    results[4][1],
2292                    results[4][2],
2293                    results[4][3],
2294                    results[4][4],
2295                    results[0],
2296                )
2297                y_position_global = float(self.pdf_object.get_y())
2298                self._add_pdf_plot(
2299                    plot_distribution,
2300                    80,
2301                    60,
2302                    x_position=10,
2303                    y_position=y_position_global,
2304                )
2305                self._add_pdf_plot(
2306                    plot_models, 80, 60, x_position=110, y_position=y_position_global
2307                )
2308            self.pdf_object.add_page()

Computes the distribution of waiting times in a trajectory dataset.

The function:

  • Calculates the waiting times as the difference between start and end times.
  • Removes missing and zero values.
  • Fits multiple statistical distributions and selects the best fit.

Parameters:

data : TrajectoriesFrame A trajectory dataset containing time-based movement data.

Returns:

tuple: - model (distfit object): The fitted distribution model. - wt (pd.Series): The processed waiting time data.

def travel_times(self, *args, **kwargs): 
2248        def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
2249            results = func(self, *args, **kwargs)
2250
2251            self.stats_frame.add_data({results[0]: results[1].model["name"]})
2252            self.stats_frame.add_data(
2253                {f"{results[0]}_params": results[1].model["params"]}
2254            )
2255
2256            func_name = results[0].replace("_", " ").split(" ")
2257            func_name[0] = func_name[0].capitalize()
2258            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", "B", size=8)
2259            self._add_pdf_cell(f"{' '.join(func_name)}")
2260            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", size=7)
2261            self._add_pdf_cell(
2262                f'Best fit: {results[1].model["name"]} with params: {results[1].model["params"]}'
2263            )
2264

2266                results[1].summary[["name", "score", "params"]]
2267            )
2268            y_position_global = float(self.pdf_object.get_y())
2269            self._add_pdf_plot(
2270                results[2], 80, 60, x_position=10, y_position=y_position_global
2271            )
2272            self._add_pdf_plot(
2273                results[3], 80, 60, x_position=110, y_position=y_position_global
2274            )
2275
2276            if len(results) == 5:
2277                self._add_pdf_cell(
2278                    f"At point {results[4][4]}, the flexion point of the distributions was found"
2279                )
2280                self._add_pdf_cell(
2281                    f'Left distribution is {results[4][0].model["name"]} with params: {results[4][0].model["params"]}'
2282                )
2283                self._add_pdf_cell(
2284                    f'Right distribution is {results[4][1].model["name"]} with params: {results[4][1].model["params"]}'
2285                )
2286                self._add_pdf_distribution_table(
2287                    results[4][1].summary[["name", "score", "params"]]
2288                )
2289                plot_distribution, plot_models = self._plot_double_distribution(
2290                    results[4][0],
2291                    results[4][1],
2292                    results[4][2],
2293                    results[4][3],
2294                    results[4][4],
2295                    results[0],
2296                )
2297                y_position_global = float(self.pdf_object.get_y())
2298                self._add_pdf_plot(
2299                    plot_distribution,
2300                    80,
2301                    60,
2302                    x_position=10,
2303                    y_position=y_position_global,
2304                )
2305                self._add_pdf_plot(
2306                    plot_models, 80, 60, x_position=110, y_position=y_position_global
2307                )
2308            self.pdf_object.add_page()

  • Calculates travel times as the time difference between consecutive trajectory points.
  • Removes missing values.
  • Fits multiple statistical distributions and selects the best fit.

Parameters:

data : TrajectoriesFrame A trajectory dataset containing time-based movement data.

Returns:

tuple: - model (distfit object): The fitted distribution model. - tt (pd.Series): The processed travel time data.

Computes the distribution of the radius of gyration (RoG).

The function:

  • Computes the radius of gyration for each trajectory.
  • Fits multiple statistical distributions and selects the best fit.

Parameters:

data : TrajectoriesFrame A trajectory dataset containing spatial movement data.

Returns:

tuple: - model (distfit object): The fitted distribution model. - rog (pd.Series): The processed radius of gyration data.

def rog_over_time(self, *args, **kwargs): 
2183        def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
2184            func_name, best_fit, param_frame, plot_obj = func(self, *args, **kwargs)
2185            filtered_df = param_frame[param_frame["curve"] == best_fit]
2186
2187            self.stats_frame.add_data({func_name: best_fit})
2188            self.stats_frame.add_data(
2189                {
2190                    f"{func_name}_params": filtered_df[
2191                        ["param1", "param2"]
2192                    ].values.tolist()
2193                }
2194            )
2195
2196            func_name = func_name.replace("_", " ").split(" ")
2197            func_name[0] = func_name[0].capitalize()
2198            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", "B", size=8)
2199            self._add_pdf_cell(f"{' '.join(func_name)}")
2200            self.pdf_object.set_font("Arial", size=7)
2201            self._add_pdf_cell(
2202                f'Best fit: {best_fit} with Param 1: {filtered_df["param1"].values[0]},'
2203                f'Param 2: {filtered_df["param2"].values[0]}'
2204            )
2205
2206            y_position_global = float(self.pdf_object.get_y())
2207            self._add_pdf_curves_table(
2208                param_frame, x_offset=10, y_offset=y_position_global + 13
2209            )
2210            self._add_pdf_plot(
2211                plot_obj=plot_obj,
2212                image_width=80,
2213                image_height=45,
2214                x_position=125,
2215                y_position=y_position_global,
2216            )

Computes the evolution of the radius of gyration (RoG) over time.

The function:

  • Computes the radius of gyration for each trajectory over time.
  • Averages the RoG values using a specified number of records.
  • Fits a curve to model the evolution of RoG.

Parameters:

data : TrajectoriesFrame A trajectory dataset containing movement data. min_records_no : int Minimum number of records required for averaging.

Returns:

tuple: - best_fit (str): Name of the best fitting model. - global_params (dict): Parameters of the best fit. - y_pred (ndarray): Predicted values from the curve fit. - expon_y_pred (ndarray): Alternative exponential model predictions. - avg_rog (pd.Series): Averaged RoG values over time. - ["Time", "Values"] (list): Column labels.

def msd_distribution(self, *args, **kwargs):

  • Averages MSD values using a specified number of records.
  • Fits a curve to model MSD behavior.
